The chat moves so fast it's giving me a headache. **Ares_God_of_Markups**: anyone want supreme brick blessed by actual war? $500 OBO **DemeterGrows**: selling holy basil, $20/oz, makes you speak in tongues **ApolloSoundCloud**: will trade feature verse for sneakers size 10.5 I'm barefoot in my apartment, wing-feet tucked under a blanket that's more holes than fabric. The Air Hermès are up to $67,000 on StockX. Someone's wearing my identity for more than I make in two years. A DM notification pops up. **RainbowConnection**: You came alone? **FastFooted98_Real**: yeah **RainbowConnection**: Video call. Now. The call connects. Iris looks exactly like someone who's been running a black market empire—exhausted, wired, surrounded by boxes in what looks like a storage unit. She's wearing gray everything. No rainbow anything. Even her hair is dyed corporate brown. "Hermes." She says it like a diagnosis. "You look like shit." "Someone stole my shoes." "Someone stole everyone's shoes. That's why you're here." She's doing something off-camera. Sounds like packing tape. "You want information? Costs extra. You want your shoes back? That's a different price. You want to know who's been fucking all of us? That's free." "Start with free." She holds up a gold business card. Even through the shitty video quality, I can see it shimmer with divine energy. "Plutus Cryptocurrency Consulting," she reads. "Your boy's been playing everyone." "Plutus is too stupid to—" "Plutus is too stupid to mastermind. He's not too stupid to facilitate." She tosses the card aside. "He provides the buyer list. Someone else does the stealing. He takes twenty percent for 'connecting opportunities.' Been doing it for months." "But he helped us—" "He sent you to Marcus to waste your time. Meanwhile, another batch of divine sneakers got authenticated and sold. Your Hermès, Bastet's Pumas, Thor's new Timberlands. All processed while you were playing detective in Jersey." My stomach drops. Not metaphorically. Physically drops, because divine anatomy is weird when you're stressed. "Who's the thief?" "That's the hundred-dollar question. Literally. Venmo me." "Are you serious right now?" "This is a business, not a charity." She shows me her phone. Twelve different payment apps open. "I've been running divine messaging services for three thousand years. You know what the market rate for messages is now? Zero. Everything's free. WhatsApp, Discord, fucking carrier pigeons are making a comeback. I had to pivot." "To crime?" "To logistics." She's offended. "I don't steal. I facilitate redistribution of underutilized assets. Big difference." "That's literally—" "Hundred dollars or I hang up." I Venmo her from my account that has $247 total. It hurts. "Nike," she says immediately. "Goddess of victory's been taking L's for so long she snapped. Has a whole operation. Plutus provides targets, she acquires product, I handle distribution. Very efficient." "Nike? She pepper-sprayed us!" "Yeah, she mentioned that. Said you cornered her in a parking lot like creeps." Iris is packing sneakers while we talk. I recognize Hephaestus's custom Vulcan 3s. "She's not evil. Just practical. You know what her student loan payment is? Eight grand a month. For a degree in Victory Sciences. What the fuck even is that?" "Where is she?" "That's not included in the hundred. But I'll throw you a freebie—she's hitting Hera tonight. Queen of the gods just copped some Off-White Jordans. Nike's got a buyer lined up for ninety grand." "Hera will literally kill her." "Hera's in Cabo with her third husband. Instagram stories, very public. Nike does her research." I'm pacing now, wing-feet leaving scorch marks on my carpet. Mrs. Chen's gonna love that. "Why are you telling me this?" Iris pauses her packing. Looks directly at the camera. For a second, I see the old her—the rainbow goddess who used to light up the sky with messages. Now she looks like every other burned-out millennial. "Because it's gotten out of hand. Nike's getting sloppy. Plutus is getting greedy. Last week they hit Artemis while she was at her overnight shift at PetSmart. She had to finish her shift in sketchers. Sketchers, Hermes. Even I have limits." "So stop them." "Can't. They know where my warehouse is. One word to the wrong god and I'm done. But you?" She smirks. "You're already at rock bottom. What've you got to lose?" "My apartment. My car. My last shred of dignity." "So nothing." She starts typing. "Nike's got a schedule. Very organized. Hits every target between 2 and 4 AM. Always uses the same van—white, no plates, smells like failure and Red Bull." "That describes half the vans in Queens." "She'll be at Hera's penthouse at 2:47 AM exactly. Fourteen minutes to get in and out. She's got Plutus monitoring Ring cameras, redirecting feeds. Very professional." "And you want me to what, exactly?" "Stop her? Join her? I don't care. But this?" She gestures at her storage unit full of stolen divine footwear. "This ends badly for everyone. Mortals are starting to notice. There's a subreddit about 'supernatural sneakers.' Vice is writing an article. We're about two viral TikToks away from full exposure." "Why should I trust you?" "Because I'm the only god still making money who isn't screwing everyone else." She holds up a pair of my Air Hermès. "Also, I've got your shoes." "Those are—" "Your special occasion pair. Still in the box. Never worn. Nike couldn't move them—too specific to you. I bought them for myself." She examines them. "Size 9.5, narrow. Wing-foot compatible. Serial number ends in 777. These are yours." My heart's racing. Those shoes are worth more than— "Twenty thousand," she says. "That's my price. For the shoes and Nike's exact route tonight." "I don't have twenty thousand. I don't have twenty." "Then get creative. Rob Plutus. Sell a kidney. Start an OnlyFans. I don't care. But these?" She waves my shoes. "These are going to a collector in Tokyo tomorrow unless you make me a better offer." The call disconnects. I'm left staring at my laptop, barefoot, broke, and now aware that the god I asked for help is the one who's been fucking us all. My phone buzzes. Bastet. Bastet: "someone just stole my backup shoes" Bastet: "WHILE I WAS WEARING THEM" Bastet: "nike just ripped them off my feet at whole foods" Bastet: "she's lost it" Bastet: "completely lost it" I text back: "I know where she'll be tonight." Bastet: "good" Bastet: "bc I just grew my claws out" Bastet: "and I haven't eaten in 37 hours" Bastet: "someone's about to learn why we used to be worshipped" I look at my wing-feet, sparking against my cheap carpet. Think about my special occasion Air Hermès in Iris's hands. Think about Nike, who I briefly dated in 2011, desperate enough to rob other gods. Think about how we all got here. Then I text Osiris: "Need a ride tonight. And maybe some of those nuggets." Osiris: "only if we hit the dollar menu" Osiris: "I've got $3.67 until Friday" The gods are going to war. In a 2003 Corolla. Over sneakers. Zeus would be so proud.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong command of voice and characterization while making some notable departures from the original chapter plan. The author has created a compelling first-person narrative from Hermes' perspective that effectively conveys his desperation and the absurdity of gods reduced to petty economics. The chapter deviates significantly from the planned "Stakeout" chapter, instead focusing on a Discord conversation with Iris that reveals Plutus's betrayal and Nike's theft operation. This change creates a more dynamic scene than the planned stakeout but loses the direct confrontation with Nike that was outlined. The author has essentially combined elements from the planned chapters 5 and 6, incorporating the Discord element while changing the revelation about Plutus. The dialogue is a particular strength, with Iris's businesslike pragmatism contrasting effectively with Hermes's desperation. Lines like "This is a business, not a charity" and "I don't steal. I facilitate redistribution of underutilized assets" efficiently characterize Iris as amoral but practical. The text messages from Bastet maintain her established voice well, particularly with "someone's about to learn why we used to be worshipped." The worldbuilding is cleverly done through small details rather than exposition - the Mount Olympus Marketplace Discord, Artemis working at PetSmart, and the specific pricing of divine sneakers all contribute to the economic desperation theme without overexplaining. However, there are some weaknesses. The chapter occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when explaining Iris's backstory and motivations. Some of the humor feels a bit forced, like the "Zeus would be so proud" closing line. The plot twist of Plutus being involved in the theft ring is somewhat predictable given his characterization as untrustworthy. The chapter maintains consistency with the character profiles, particularly Hermes's financial anxiety and Iris's businesslike amorality. The writing successfully captures the conversational but bitter tone established in the writing plan, with short punchy sentences during moments of stress. Overall, while the chapter deviates from the original plan, it maintains the core themes of divine obsolescence and economic desperation while advancing the plot in an engaging way. The change actually creates more tension by revealing the betrayal earlier and setting up a confrontation with Nike. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 12 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 6: If the Shoe Fits Hera's penthouse is the kind of place that makes you understand why French peasants invented the guillotine. Forty-seventh floor, Central Park views, a doorman who definitely judges your net worth before buzzing you in. We're across the street in Osiris's Corolla, which now sounds like it's digesting itself. "That's her." Bastet points with a nugget. We got a twenty-piece. It's been our only food for six hours. White van, no plates, parked in the loading zone like it belongs there. Nike emerges wearing all black, a Supreme fanny pack, and Balenciaga sneakers that probably cost more than our combined checking accounts. "She really went full hypebeast," Osiris mutters. "There's Plutus." I spot him on the corner, laptop out, hunched over like a gremlin. "Probably hacking the security feeds." It's 2:43 AM. Four minutes until Nike makes her move. "What's the plan?" Bastet asks. "Because if we're doing this, I need to know whether to file my claws for maiming or murder." "We intercept," I say. "Get the shoes. Find out who else is involved. Maybe don't commit murder." "Boring, but okay." We exit the Corolla. Three gods in borrowed, terrible footwear. Osiris found some Crocs at Goodwill. Bastet's wearing her dead assistant Keith's Vans (he quit via text after the Dunkin' incident). I've got plastic bags wrapped around my wing-feet, secured with duct tape. We look like a community theater production of poverty. Nike's already inside. Plutus is so focused on his screen he doesn't notice us until Bastet's claws are at his throat. "Oh fuck," he squeaks. "Hey guys. Crazy running into you here. I was just—" "Shut up." Bastet's pupils are full slit. "Drop the laptop." He drops it. The screen shows six different security feeds, all looping footage from an hour ago. Professional setup for someone who claims to be broke. "You sold us out," I say. "It's not personal! It's just business!" He's sweating pre-workout. "Do you know how hard it is to monetize being the god of wealth when you have no wealth? It's like being the god of irony!" "You're going to tell us everything," Osiris says, and his death-god voice makes the air taste like formaldehyde. "Okay! Okay! Nike approached me two months ago. Said she had a business proposition. Twenty percent for providing intel on which gods had valuable shoes and when they'd be vulnerable. I'm just the information guy!" "Who else?" Bastet's drawing blood. Just a little. "Iris handles distribution! There's a few others—Morpheus drugs gods to sleep first sometimes, Dionysus gets them drunk—it's a whole operation! Very organized! I have a PowerPoint!" "A PowerPoint?" I can't help but ask. "Nike insisted on proper documentation. She runs it like a startup. We have quarterly projections!" A crash from inside. Nike's not being subtle. "Watch him," I tell Bastet, then run for the entrance. The doorman's asleep—Morpheus's work, probably. The elevator's waiting, like someone wanted us to follow. Forty-seventh floor. The penthouse door is open. I creep inside, plastic bags crinkling with every step. Hera's place is exactly what you'd expect from the Queen of Gods—marble everything, gold accents, a painting of herself above the fireplace that definitely cost more than a mortal's house. Nike's in the master bedroom, stuffing sneakers into a duffel bag. "Hermes." She doesn't look up. "Was wondering when you'd show." "Nike." "Don't." She zips the bag. "Whatever speech you've got about how we used to mean something, how we're better than this—save it. You know what victory means now? Engagement metrics. Stock prices. Getting the W on a sneaker drop. That's my domain now." She turns. She looks exhausted. We dated for three months back when she was still trying to make the Olympics matter again. Even then, she was intense about winning. "You pepper-sprayed me," I point out. "You cornered me in a parking lot at 3 AM. What was I supposed to do, have a feelings talk?" She hefts the bag. "I've got twelve pairs here. Street value: four hundred grand. My cut after everyone gets paid: forty thousand. That covers five months of student loans." "This is insane." "This is adaptation." She pulls out pepper spray again. "You want to know what's insane? Ares has a TikTok where he rates military fails. Aphrodite does couples counseling on Instagram Live. You deliver Thai food to mortals who don't tip. We're all insane. I'm just profitable." "Those are Hera's shoes." "Hera's in Cabo with husband number three, posting thirst traps at fifty-seven hundred years old." Nike checks her watch. "I've got four minutes before Plutus's loops expire. You letting me walk or are we doing this?" I think about my Air Hermès in Iris's storage unit. About Bastet losing her sponsorships. About Osiris eating McDonald's like it's the only thing keeping him corporeal. "We're doing this." Nike sighs. "You were always too sentimental." She doesn't use the pepper spray. She goes for the taser in her fanny pack. But my plastic-bag shoes are apparently non-conductive, because the electricity just makes my wing-feet tingle. I tackle her into Hera's California King bed. We roll, two minor deities wrestling over a bag of sneakers worth more than most people's lives. She's got victory strength but I've got desperation. The bag splits. Shoes everywhere. Off-White Jordans, Travis Scott Fragments, Sean Wotherspoon Air Maxes—a rainbow of late-stage capitalism scattered across Egyptian cotton sheets. "You idiots!" A new voice. We freeze. Iris stands in the doorway, gray everything, looking deeply disappointed. Behind her, Bastet's dragging a zip-tied Plutus. "Security's coming back online in ninety seconds," Iris says. "And you're having a slap fight on Hera's bed. She has that thing blessed! Do you know what bodily fluids on blessed surfaces do?" We scramble apart. Nike goes for the window. Bastet trips her with a casual claw swipe. "Sixty seconds," Iris updates. "Decide now. Take the shoes and run, or stay and explain to NYPD why you're robbing the Queen of Gods." "Why are you helping?" I ask. "I'm not. I'm protecting my investment. If you all get arrested, my supply chain collapses." She's already picking up scattered sneakers. "Forty-five seconds." "This isn't over," Nike spits at me. "Yeah, it is." I grab a pair of Hera's Jordans. They're my size. Divine recognition. "You went too far." "Thirty seconds!" We run. Five gods and a bag of stolen stolen goods. Down forty-seven flights because the elevator's mysteriously broken. Osiris is waiting with the engine running, because he's the only one who thought ahead. "Drive!" Bastet shoves Plutus in the trunk. "Fucking drive!" We peel out as the first police sirens wail. Five gods in a Corolla that shouldn't be moving, with enough felony footwear to put us away forever. "So," Osiris says, merging into traffic like nothing happened. "Anyone else think maybe we should have just gotten regular jobs?" "Shut up," Nike mutters from the floor, zip-tied with Plutus's laptop cable. "Just shut up." I look back at Hera's building. Blue lights flashing. Security running around like ants. "Iris?" I ask. "What now?" She's counting shoes. "Now? Now we negotiate. Unless you want to explain this to Zeus when Hera gets back from Cabo." My wing-feet are burning through the plastic bags. Nike's crying in the backseat—victory goddess tears smell like participation trophies. Plutus is screaming from the trunk about his laptop. Just another Tuesday night in the divine gig economy.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates a strong command of voice and tone, creating a world where ancient gods struggle with modern economic realities through the lens of sneaker culture. The writing effectively captures Hermes' bitter, anxious first-person perspective while maintaining the planned conversational style. The chapter deviates significantly from the original chapter plan titled "The Group Chat," which was supposed to involve a Discord server where gods share sneaker-selling tips. Instead, we get a heist/confrontation scene at Hera's penthouse. This deviation isn't necessarily bad—the chapter still advances the core plot about divine sneaker theft—but it represents a substantial departure from the outlined plan. Character consistency is generally strong. Hermes maintains his bitter, desperate persona. Nike embodies her "victory at all costs" mentality while revealing genuine financial struggles. Plutus is appropriately pathetic and entrepreneurial. Iris appears as the cold, efficient businesswoman described in her profile. Bastet's feline qualities and pragmatism shine through. The addition of Osiris (not in the original character profiles) is handled well enough, though he lacks distinctive characterization. The dialogue effectively reveals character and advances plot, with each god having a distinctive voice. Nike's "You know what victory means now? Engagement metrics" perfectly captures her character's evolution. The banter feels natural for desperate, immortal beings caught in a heist. The writing avoids purple prose and forced metaphors, instead relying on specific, concrete details that build the world: plastic bags taped around wing-feet, the smell of "victory goddess tears," Hera's California King bed. These details effectively blend the mythological with the mundane. The chapter maintains the planned bitter humor and financial anxiety central to the concept. Lines like "We look like a community theater production of poverty" effectively blend comedy with genuine desperation. However, there are weaknesses. The chapter sometimes tells rather than shows, particularly regarding characters' emotions. The plot feels somewhat rushed, with convenient timing and easy solutions (like the plastic bags protecting against the taser). Some character motivations remain unclear, particularly why Iris helps them escape. The chapter also introduces elements not previously established (Osiris's car, Hera's penthouse) without sufficient context. While these aren't major issues, they do affect the coherence of the narrative. Overall, this is a strong chapter that captures the intended tone and themes of gods struggling with modern economic realities through the lens of sneaker culture. Despite deviating from the original plan, it maintains the core concept and delivers an entertaining, character-driven scene with distinctive voice and humor. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 15 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 8 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 7: Soul and Sole Iris's warehouse in Long Island City smells like sneakers and shattered dreams. It's 4 AM and we're sitting on boxes of stolen divinity like the world's saddest corporate retreat. Nike's zip-tied to a chair. Plutus is calculating his losses on his phone. Bastet's grooming her claws. Osiris is eating the last nugget. "Let's review," Iris says, pacing between towers of shoe boxes. "You broke into Hera's penthouse. Stole shoes I was going to fence anyway. Got caught on thirteen security cameras. And brought the entire operation to my warehouse." "When you put it like that—" I start. "Shut up." She pulls out a tablet. "Hera lands in six hours. When she sees her collection's gone, she'll call Zeus. When Zeus finds out someone's been systematically robbing gods, he'll call a summit. When they trace the security footage, they'll find you idiots." "So we're fucked," Bastet summarizes. "You're fucked. I'm incorporated in Delaware." Iris shows us her business license. "Rainbow Logistics LLC. Fully legitimate shipping company. I just move boxes. What's in them? Not my concern." "You literal—" "BUT." She holds up a hand. "I'm willing to help. For a price." "We don't have money," I remind her. "I don't want money. I want out." She gestures at the warehouse. "Do you think this is fun? Managing inventory of divine Nikes? Dealing with sneakerhead collectors who want to authenticate the 'energy signature' of used Yeezys? I'm a messaging goddess. I used to paint the sky." Nike laughs from her chair. "Join the club. I used to crown champions. Now I sell their shoes on StockX." "Exactly." Iris pulls up a spreadsheet that makes my eyes bleed. "Six months ago, I had a nice little business. Move some divine items, take a small cut, everyone's happy. Then Nike scales up. Plutus brings in more desperate gods. Suddenly I'm running a full criminal enterprise." "You could have said no," Osiris points out. "With what leverage? They knew where my warehouse was. My business model. One word to the wrong god and I'm finished." She scrolls through inventory. "So I kept going. Moved their products. Took my cut. Told myself it was temporary." "It's never temporary," Nike says quietly. "The hustle becomes you. I know. I've been grinding so long I forgot what victory actually feels like." We sit with that for a moment. Five gods in a warehouse full of stolen pieces of ourselves. "What do you want?" I ask Iris. "Clean slate. We return everything. Every shoe. Every divine item. Gods get their stuff back, I shut down the operation, we all pretend this never happened." "That's it?" "That's it." She pulls up another screen. "I've got everything catalogued. Three hundred pairs of divine sneakers. Combined street value: twelve million. Every god who's been hit, I know where their stuff is." "And if we don't agree?" Bastet asks. "Then I liquidate everything tonight. Dump it all on the market at once. Crash the divine economy. Let chaos sort it out." "You wouldn't—" She shows us her phone. One button. "Everything's already listed. Just have to hit confirm." "That's our entire culture," Plutus says, suddenly caring. "Our identity. You'd destroy it for—" "For freedom from this bullshit? Yes." Iris looks tired. Ancient tired. "I'm three thousand years old. I've delivered messages between gods who hate each other, love each other, scheme against each other. You know what I've learned? We're all just trying to survive. But this?" She gestures at the warehouse. "This isn't survival. It's just sad." "So what's your plan?" I ask. "Simple. We stage a return. Anonymous drops at every god's door. They wake up, their shoes are back. Maybe a note about securing their belongings better. Nike takes the fall for the ones we can't return—" "Excuse me?" Nike struggles against the zip ties. "You're already on camera at Hera's. Might as well own it." Iris shrugs. "Or we all go down together. Your choice." I look around. At Nike, who turned desperation into crime. At Plutus, who monetized misery. At Bastet, who lost everything for being herself. At Osiris, who's just trying to exist. At myself, barefoot because I couldn't afford to be divine anymore. "There's another option," I say. Everyone looks at me. "We tell the truth." "Are you insane?" Plutus drops his phone. "Think about it. We've all been hiding. Pretending we're not struggling. Acting like everything's fine while we sell pieces of ourselves." I stand up, plastic bags crinkling. "What if we just... didn't?" "They'll judge us," Nike says. "They're already judging us. At least this way it's honest." Bastet laughs. "You want to tell Zeus we've been robbing each other because we can't make rent?" "Yes." "Tell Hera her Jordans are gone because Nike needed loan money?" "Yes." "Admit we're all failures who can't adapt to the modern world?" "We're not failures." I'm pacing now, wing-feet sparking. "We're survivors. We went from being worshipped to being Uber drivers. From temples to studio apartments. And we're still here." "Barely," Osiris mutters. "But here." I turn to Iris. "You said it yourself. We're all just trying to survive. So let's stop pretending it's easy." "This is insane," Plutus says. "This whole situation is insane!" I gesture at the warehouse. "We're gods! Arguing over sneakers! In a warehouse in Queens! At four in the morning! Because we can't afford to exist!" Silence. Then Nike starts laughing. Not happy laughing. The kind that comes when you're too tired to cry anymore. "You know what? Fuck it." She looks at Iris. "Cut me loose. I'll return Hera's shoes myself. Tell her exactly why I took them. If she wants to smite me, at least I'll go out honest." "You're serious," Iris says. "Victory isn't just about winning anymore." Nike's voice is steady. "Sometimes it's about admitting you lost." Iris looks at me. At all of us. Then she picks up scissors. "This is either the best or worst idea ever," she says, cutting Nike free. "Probably both," I admit. "If we're doing this," Bastet says, "I want my Pumas back first. If I'm facing divine judgment, I'm doing it in my own shoes." Iris nods. Starts pulling boxes. "Everyone gets their primary pairs. The rest we return with explanations. Full transparency." "This is going to end so badly," Plutus moans. "Maybe." I find my work Air Hermès. Slide them on. My wing-feet sing with relief. "But at least it'll end honestly." "So what now?" Osiris asks. I look at my phone. 4:47 AM. Sun's coming up soon. Deliveries start at 6. "Now? We return some shoes. Face some consequences. Maybe change how we do things." I look at Nike. "All of us." She nods. "I know where to find everyone. Who gets hit with the truth first?" "Zeus," Iris says. "If we're burning it all down, might as well start at the top." Five gods in a warehouse, about to commit the ultimate divine crime: honesty. "Anyone else terrified?" Bastet asks. We all raise our hands. "Good," she says. "Let's go disappoint our ancestors."
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively delivers on the premise of gods struggling in the modern world, with divine sneakers as the central conceit. The writing successfully captures Hermes' first-person voice as established in the character profile—bitter, anxious, and conversational. The chapter takes place at the climactic confrontation with Iris, the mastermind behind the sneaker theft operation, though it deviates somewhat from the original chapter plan. The strongest element is the thematic resonance. The chapter effectively conveys the pathos of ancient deities reduced to gig economy workers and petty criminals. Lines like "We're gods! Arguing over sneakers! In a warehouse in Queens! At four in the morning! Because we can't afford to exist!" encapsulate the absurdity and tragedy of their situation. The dialogue generally rings true to the established character voices, particularly Nike's defeated pragmatism and Iris's businesslike amorality. However, the chapter diverges significantly from the planned Chapter 7 ("Just Business"). According to the plan, this chapter was supposed to feature a meeting at Foot Locker where Hephaestus works, with Iris revealed as the scammer who stole Hermes' shoes to sell them to his landlord. Instead, we get a warehouse confrontation with Iris already captured, and a pivot toward a resolution where the gods decide to come clean about their struggles. This represents a major tonal shift from the planned cynical ending toward something more cathartic and community-oriented. The writing occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when explaining Iris's backstory and motivations. Some of the emotional beats feel rushed, especially Nike's sudden change of heart. The warehouse setting is minimally described, missing opportunities for sensory details that could have enhanced the scene's atmosphere. Dialogue is generally strong, with each character maintaining a distinct voice, though some exchanges feel a bit on-the-nose in articulating the theme. The chapter maintains coherence despite the deviation from the plan, and the emotional arc—from confrontation to a decision to embrace honesty—is clear and effective. The chapter remains faithful to the core premise of "Gods wore sneakers" and maintains the established world rules where divine sneakers suppress godly "tells" and are essential to their functioning in the modern world. The economic anxiety and gig economy struggles central to the concept are present throughout. Overall, this chapter succeeds in delivering an emotionally resonant scene that captures the core concept of divine beings struggling with modern economic realities, though it deviates from the planned plot points and occasionally relies on exposition rather than scene work. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 9 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 8: Barefoot Zeus's "emergency office" is a WeWork in Midtown because of course it is. The King of Gods hot-desks between a startup that makes AI-generated affirmations and a company selling CBD for pets. He's wearing his lightning-bolt Jordans and a Patagonia vest, trying to look "approachable." "So," he says, staring at the five of us like disappointed dad energy incarnate. "Someone want to explain why Hera's screaming about stolen shoes?" It's 9 AM. We've been returning sneakers since dawn. Most gods didn't answer their doors. The ones who did were either confused, angry, or both. Demeter cried when she got her garden Crocs back. Apollo immediately checked StockX to see if they'd appreciated. "We stole them," Nike says. No preamble. No excuses. "I stole them. To sell. For money." Zeus's eye twitches. "You stole from gods? From family?" "From gods who could afford it," she clarifies. "Or at least gods who had something worth stealing." "That's your defense?" "I'm not defending anything. I'm explaining." Nike pulls out her phone, shows him her student loan balance. "Eight thousand a month. For a degree that promised to make me 'recession-proof.' Victory doesn't pay bills anymore." "So you became a thief?" "I became practical." The WeWork's glass walls mean everyone can see Zeus getting increasingly red. The CBD pet guys are taking photos. "And you?" He turns to me. "Hermes? My messenger?" "I deliver for DoorDash," I say. "And Uber Eats. And Instacart. And any other app that'll have me. My sneakers cost more than my rent, which I can't afford anyway." "That's not my—" "Whose problem is it then?" Bastet interrupts. "I lost three million followers because someone filmed my real eyes. Three million. Do you know what that means in the mortal economy?" "I told you all to adapt—" "We did!" Osiris stands. "I drive for Lyft with a car held together by death essence and prayer. Plutus sells crypto courses to desperate mortals. Iris runs a shipping company for contraband. We adapted. We're just not good at it." Zeus looks at Plutus. "You too?" Plutus shrugs. "God of wealth with no wealth is just... ironic. And irony doesn't monetize well. Trust me, I tried." "This is insane," Zeus mutters. "Yes," I agree. "It is. We're gods doing gig work. We're mythology with side hustles. We're divinity with credit card debt. It's all insane." "So you stole from each other?" "We stole from ourselves," Iris corrects. "Every shoe taken was just another god trying to survive. Nike took from those who had. I moved product. Plutus provided information. We created our own economy of desperation." Zeus slumps in his ergonomic chair. The King of Gods, defeated by late-stage capitalism. "What do you want me to do?" he asks finally. "I can't make mortals worship us again. I can't create jobs for every minor deity who can't figure out LinkedIn." "We don't want you to," Nike says. "We just wanted you to know. To stop pretending everything's fine when gods are selling plasma to make rent." "Ares sells plasma?" "Twice a week," I confirm. "Says it's for the free cookies, but..." Zeus looks out at Manhattan, at the mortals rushing to their own gigs, their own hustles, their own desperate attempts to exist. "Fine," he says eventually. "No punishment. But the stealing stops. Now." "Already stopped," Nike confirms. "Iris shut down the operation. Everyone got their shoes back. Even Hera, though she's still mad about the bed." "The bed?" "Don't ask." Zeus stands. His Jordans squeak on the WeWork floor. "Is that it then? You commit divine crimes, confess, and we all just... move on?" "What else is there?" I ask. "Smite us? We're already struggling. Banish us? To where, Jersey? We're gods, but we're also just trying to exist in a world that doesn't need us anymore." He looks at each of us. Nike, defiant but exhausted. Iris, already checking her phone for legitimate shipping jobs. Plutus, probably planning his next scheme. Bastet, pupils finally normal behind prescription sunglasses. Osiris, just happy to not be in his Corolla. Me, in my beat-up Air Hermès, wing-feet visible through the holes. "Team meeting," Zeus announces. "All gods. Tomorrow. We're going to figure this out." "Figure what out?" Bastet asks. "How to be gods in a world with Venmo." He heads for the door, stops. "And maybe set up some kind of divine unemployment fund. Just until everyone gets stable." He leaves. The pet CBD guys are definitely live-tweeting this. "Did we just...win?" Nike asks. "Nobody won," Iris says. "We just stopped losing for a second." My phone buzzes. Delivery notification. $12 order, probably no tip, definitely going to a fifth-floor walkup. I look at the others. "I gotta go. Rent's still due." "Same," Osiris says. "Airport run in an hour." We disperse. Gods returning to their gigs, their hustles, their attempts to matter in a world of metrics and monetization. Outside, I'm lacing up my Air Hermès when Nike catches up. "Hermes." "Yeah?" "I'm sorry. About the pepper spray. And the stealing. And..." She gestures vaguely at everything. "We're all sorry about something." She nods. Checks her phone. "I've got a SoulCycle class to teach at ten. They think I'm just really enthusiastic about winning." "Are you?" "I'm enthusiastic about the employee discount." She starts walking, stops. "Maybe we could grab coffee sometime? When we can afford coffee?" "Yeah. Maybe." She leaves. I watch her go, victory goddess in Balenciaga sneakers she definitely couldn't afford, off to help mortals feel accomplished on stationary bikes. My delivery app pings. Then pings again. The algorithm has forgiven my morning cancellations and wants me back. I check the first order. Thai food, going to Mrs. Chen's building. She always tips cash, always pretends my wing-feet are normal. Sometimes she orders extra spring rolls "by accident." I accept the order. Start walking. My Air Hermès are falling apart, sole separating from upper, divine essence leaking with every step. But they're mine. They're me. Three blocks later, I pass a Foot Locker. There's a hiring sign in the window. "Seeking Associates with Shoe Knowledge." I take a photo, send it to the group chat we definitely shouldn't have made. Hermes: anyone want a real job? Bastet: does it pay more than plasma? Plutus: what's the commission structure? Nike: can we steal from the register? Iris: I'm not going back to retail Osiris: do they offer health insurance? I pocket my phone, keep walking. Maybe gods wear sneakers because we're all just trying to stay grounded. Maybe we steal from each other because we've forgotten how to share. Maybe we hustle because we don't know how to just exist anymore. Or maybe we're all just broke and doing our best. My delivery bag bounces against my hip. Mrs. Chen's Thai food's getting cold. Time to fly—or at least hover-jog really fast. I'm Hermes. Former messenger of the gods. Current delivery driver for apps that rate me in stars. Future... something. Probably still this, but with health insurance if I'm lucky. My Air Hermès squeak with every step. They sound like prayers. Or maybe just poverty. Either way, I keep walking. Five stars would really help me out.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively concludes the story of gods struggling in the modern gig economy, maintaining the bitter, cynical tone established in the writing plan. The author has created a finale that brings the central characters together for a confrontation with Zeus that serves as both climax and commentary on the economic realities facing these once-powerful deities. The chapter excels in its consistent voice—Hermes narrates with the same weary, sardonic tone established in the character profile. His observations about Zeus's WeWork office and the irony of gods selling plasma are particularly effective. The dialogue is sharp and economical, revealing character through brief exchanges rather than exposition. The author skillfully incorporates specific details that ground these mythological figures in mundane reality: Zeus in a Patagonia vest, Osiris's car "held together by death essence and prayer," and the telling detail of Hermes' wing-feet visible through holes in his shoes. These concrete images effectively communicate the gods' diminished status without heavy-handed explanation. However, the chapter occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when explaining the gods' various side hustles. Some of these explanations feel like information dumps rather than organic revelations. The confrontation with Zeus resolves somewhat too neatly with his sudden decision to create a "divine unemployment fund," which feels like a hasty solution to the complex economic problems established throughout the story. The dialogue generally works well, though some exchanges feel slightly mechanical, serving primarily to advance plot points rather than revealing deeper character. The final group chat sequence, while clever, reads more like a writer's device than an organic conversation. The chapter follows the planned ending of "solving nothing fundamental" while still providing some sense of closure. The final image of Hermes continuing his deliveries effectively reinforces the story's central theme: these gods are trapped in an economic system that diminishes them, yet they persist. The author successfully avoids the pitfalls outlined in the writing plan: there's no neat resolution, no character growth, and the gods remain unlikable yet compelling. The sneaker culture and gig economy elements remain central to the narrative, with divine powers serving as metaphors for human struggles rather than magical solutions. Overall, this chapter delivers a satisfying conclusion to a story about divine beings facing very human problems. It maintains the cynical, economically anxious tone established in the writing plan while providing just enough resolution to feel complete. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This creative piece takes the prompt "Gods wore sneakers" and develops it into a contemporary urban fantasy about fallen deities struggling in the gig economy. The story follows Hermes, a delivery driver god who discovers his divine sneakers have been stolen, leading him into a conspiracy of gods stealing from each other to survive in a world that no longer worships them. The strongest aspect of this piece is its worldbuilding. The author creates a compelling vision of ancient gods reduced to modern hustles - Hermes doing DoorDash, Bastet as a social media influencer, Osiris driving for Lyft. The juxtaposition of divine powers with mundane struggles creates both humor and pathos. The concept of divine sneakers as both literal footwear and metaphorical connections to godly powers is cleverly executed. Character development is nuanced and consistent throughout. Hermes maintains his messenger essence while being beaten down by modern capitalism. The supporting cast each has distinct personalities that align with their mythological origins while being updated for contemporary relevance. Nike's transformation from antagonist to sympathetic character feels earned through the revelation of her desperate circumstances. The dialogue is sharp, contemporary, and distinctive for each character. It effectively conveys personality and advances the plot without becoming exposition-heavy. The text messages and Discord conversations feel authentic to modern communication while maintaining the divine personalities behind them. The pacing is generally strong, with each chapter advancing the plot while revealing more about this world. The story moves efficiently from discovery to investigation to confrontation to resolution. However, the middle chapters (particularly 4-5) occasionally drag with repetitive elements of the investigation. The emotional core of the story - gods struggling with irrelevance and poverty - remains consistent and compelling. The author avoids the trap of making the gods too powerful or too pathetic, instead finding a balance that makes their struggles relatable despite their divine nature. Some weaknesses include occasional overreliance on modern slang and references that might date quickly. There are a few instances where the metaphors become slightly forced ("My stomach drops. Not metaphorically. Physically drops, because divine anatomy is weird when you're stressed."). The resolution with Zeus feels somewhat too easy given the buildup of tension. The prose occasionally veers into purple territory with descriptions of divine essence and wing-feet, but generally maintains a good balance between descriptive and functional language. The author effectively uses short, punchy sentences to maintain momentum during action sequences. Overall, this is a creative, coherent response to the prompt that successfully maintains its premise and character development across multiple chapters. It blends mythology with contemporary issues in a way that feels fresh rather than forced. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Pacing: 16 World Building: 19 Compelling Plot: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19
Avg Final Item Score: 84.7/100
+ Sci-Fi First Contact — First Contact (Chapter Avg: 81.0 | Final: 77.6)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Sci-Fi First Contact Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: A month ago the megastructures arrived. First, the fish started dying. Then they spoke.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Sci-Fi First Contact Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: A month ago the megastructures arrived. First, the fish started dying. Then they spoke. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming **Tone Options:** - Horror/cosmic dread - the megastructures as incomprehensible threats - Hard sci-fi mystery - scientific investigation of the phenomena - Ecological thriller - focus on environmental catastrophe - Philosophical/literary - meditation on communication and understanding - Military thriller - humanity's response to potential invasion - Intimate character study - personal stories against cosmic backdrop **Character Possibilities:** - Marine biologist studying the fish deaths - Government official coordinating response - Fisherman whose livelihood is destroyed - Child who first hears the voices - Linguist trying to decode the communication - Military commander planning defense - Journalist covering the story - Religious leader interpreting the events - AI researcher analyzing patterns - Environmental activist who predicted this **Plot Directions:** - The megastructures are arks fleeing a dying universe - They're harvesters treating Earth like a farm - They're trying to warn us about something worse coming - The fish deaths are accidental - we're like ants to them - They're testing humanity's worthiness - The structures are actually Earth's own creation from the future - They're interdimensional beings bleeding into our reality - They communicate through death itself - First contact gone wrong - they don't realize we're sentient - They're refugees seeking help **Story Beats Across 8 Chapters:** Version 1 (Mystery/Investigation): 1. Fish deaths begin, protagonist introduced 2. Pattern discovered, megastructures observed 3. First communication attempts 4. Decoding the message 5. Revelation of their purpose 6. Humanity's response fractures 7. Direct contact established 8. Resolution/new equilibrium Version 2 (Escalating Horror): 1. Subtle wrongness, dead fish 2. Mass die-offs, economic collapse 3. First whispers in the static 4. Voices become clearer, more disturbing 5. True nature revealed 6. Humanity's failed attempts to respond 7. Point of no return 8. Transformation/ending Version 3 (Human Drama): 1. Multiple POVs introduced during crisis 2. Personal stakes established 3. Communities fragment 4. Unexpected alliances form 5. Communication breakthrough 6. Moral dilemmas emerge 7. Sacrifice required 8. Bittersweet resolution **Pacing Options:** - Slow burn: Gradual revelation over 6 chapters, rapid conclusion - Steady escalation: Each chapter raises stakes - Three act structure: Chapters 1-3 setup, 4-6 confrontation, 7-8 resolution - Parallel timelines: Past/present or multiple POVs - Real-time: Each chapter is one day/week **The Megastructures Could Be:** - Dyson spheres or rings - Organic/living entities - Geometric impossibilities - Ships or habitats - Weapons or tools - Art or communication devices - Interdimensional anchors - Temporal constructs **Why Fish First:** - They communicate through water/sound - Fish are telepathic receivers - Structures need biological material - Ocean temperatures/chemistry affected - Fish are early warning system - Accidental electromagnetic interference - They're sampling Earth's biosphere - Fish deaths are the message itself # Reflection Looking at these brainstormed ideas, several elements stand out as particularly compelling: **What Works:** - The marine biologist protagonist offers natural expertise and emotional investment - The progression from environmental disaster to first contact creates strong narrative momentum - The mystery of "why fish?" provides an intriguing hook that demands resolution - Multiple POV characters could showcase different aspects of humanity's response - The slow revelation of the megastructures' nature allows for building dread/wonder **What Might Not Work:** - Pure horror might be too limiting for 8 chapters - Military thriller could feel generic - Too many POV characters might fragment the narrative - Time loop or alternate timeline concepts might overcomplicate a short story **Strong Combinations:** - A marine biologist protagonist with supporting cast including a linguist and government official - Mystery/investigation tone with elements of cosmic wonder rather than pure horror - The megastructures attempting to communicate through the only medium they understand - water/biological systems - Fish deaths as unintended consequence of communication attempts, not malicious - Building to a revelation that challenges human assumptions about intelligence and communication **Pacing Considerations:** - 8 chapters of ~1000 words each needs tight focus - Can't afford extensive worldbuilding or too many subplots - Should maintain mystery while providing satisfying progress each chapter - Final revelation needs proper setup without feeling rushed The most compelling approach seems to be a character-driven scientific mystery that explores themes of communication, environmental interconnection, and humanity's place in a larger cosmos. The fish deaths work as both an environmental catastrophe and a failed first attempt at contact, leading to increasingly successful communication attempts that reveal the true nature and purpose of the visitors.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention **Core Concept:** This will be a character-driven scientific mystery that explores first contact through the lens of environmental catastrophe. The story follows Dr. Elena Vasquez, a marine biologist, as she investigates mass fish deaths that herald humanity's first contact with an alien intelligence attempting to communicate through Earth's hydrosphere. **Tone & Style:** I'll aim for a grounded, scientific realism with moments of cosmic wonder. The prose will be clear and accessible, with technical elements explained through character interactions rather than exposition. The horror will be existential rather than visceral - the fear of the unknown and humanity's smallness, not gore or jump scares. **Voice:** Third-person limited, primarily following Elena but occasionally shifting to key supporting characters for crucial perspectives. The voice will be observational and precise, reflecting the scientific mindset while allowing for emotional depth. **Plot Approach:** The megastructures are revealed to be vast consciousness-vessels from an aquatic civilization. The fish deaths are unintended casualties of their attempts to establish communication through bio-electrical fields in water. As humanity learns to "speak" with them, we discover they're refugees warning of an approaching cosmic threat while seeking safe harbor. **What I'll Aim For:** - Realistic scientific process and collaboration - Genuine human reactions to the impossible - Building mystery that pays off logically - Environmental themes without preaching - Communication as puzzle-solving - Hope despite catastrophe **What I'll Avoid:** - Military antagonism as primary response - Technobabble without purpose - Making the aliens too human-like - Deus ex machina solutions - Excessive government conspiracy subplots - Nihilistic endings # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: "The Silent Shoals" (~1000 words)** Dr. Elena Vasquez investigates unprecedented fish deaths off the Pacific Northwest coast. Introduction to the scale of the die-offs, Elena's expertise, and first glimpse of the megastructures through telescope data from her colleague at NASA. Ends with Elena discovering the fish aren't just dying - they're dying in patterns. **Chapter 2: "Patterns in the Deep" (~1000 words)** Elena presents her findings to an emergency conference. The patterns match electromagnetic frequencies. Dr. James Chen, a linguist specializing in xenolinguistics theory, recognizes potential communication markers. Government liaison Sarah Martinez announces global coordination efforts. The chapter ends with the first "voice" - a low-frequency pulse through the ocean that Elena's equipment barely captures. **Chapter 3: "Translation" (~1000 words)** Three weeks into the crisis. Elena and James work together, using AI to analyze the increasingly complex patterns. Fish deaths are accelerating but becoming more localized - the entities are learning. Breakthrough: the patterns aren't just communication, they're questions. "Where is your water-mind?" The team realizes the aliens think Earth's oceans are a single conscious entity. **Chapter 4: "Contact Protocols" (~1000 words)** The team attempts to respond using underwater electromagnetic arrays. Initial attempts fail catastrophically, causing more deaths. Elena has an insight - they need living intermediaries. Using trained dolphins and whales fitted with neural interfaces, they establish crude two-way communication. First successful exchange reveals the aliens are called the Confluence. **Chapter 5: "The Confluence" (~1000 words)** Direct communication established. The Confluence explains through improving translation that they are refugees from a universe where entropy is accelerating. They perceived Earth's oceans as a potential consciousness to commune with. They express horror at the deaths they've caused and share imagery of their water-world civilization. Sarah coordinates global response as humanity grapples with the implications. **Chapter 6: "The Warning" (~1000 words)** The Confluence reveals why they fled - an expanding wave of reality dissolution that consumes everything. They've been seeking civilizations advanced enough to help solve the problem or at least preserve knowledge. Time is limited; the wave will reach Earth's region of space within decades. Global unity fractures as nations debate whether to trust the warning. **Chapter 7: "Synthesis" (~1000 words)** Elena discovers the Confluence can teach humanity to preserve consciousness in water itself - a form of biological quantum computing. Some see salvation, others see the end of humanity as we know it. Elena must decide whether to be among the first to undergo the process to better facilitate communication. James reveals multiple world governments are preparing both defensive and offensive responses. **Chapter 8: "New Tides" (~1000 words)** Six months later. Elena, now partially merged with the ocean's consciousness, helps coordinate humanity's response. The fish have returned, evolved with new neural structures that allow them to serve as communication nodes. Humanity prepares for the cosmic threat while learning from the Confluence. The story ends with Elena teaching a child to "listen" to the ocean's new voice - hope for adaptation and survival through transformation rather than resistance.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# How a Human Might Approach This Prompt A human writer would likely start with a visceral reaction: "Holy shit, the fish are dying and then they SPOKE?" They'd probably fixate on one powerful image - maybe dead fish washing up on their hometown beach, or their kid's goldfish floating belly-up. They might draw from personal fears about climate change, the ocean's mysteries, or that creepy feeling of swimming in dark water. Humans tend to write from emotional cores outward. They'd likely pick a specific beach they know, a real coastal town, maybe base Elena on their marine biologist friend or that professor who changed their life. They'd remember the smell of rotting fish, the way seagulls sound, how their dad used to take them fishing. A human might approach this with: - Dark humor about bureaucratic responses to alien contact - Petty human concerns persisting during cosmic events - Characters who are bad at their jobs sometimes - Messy, unresolved relationships - Specific cultural references and in-jokes - Political commentary that's actually biting - Sex, death, bathroom breaks, bad coffee - Characters who say the wrong thing at the wrong time # Common LLM Writing Failings **The Safety Dance:** - Every conflict resolves neatly - Violence is sanitized or absent - Sex/bodily functions don't exist - Nobody is truly bad, just "misunderstood" - Controversial topics are sidestepped **The Impressive Vocabulary Syndrome:** - Using "utilize" instead of "use" - Purple prose masquerading as literary - Every sunset is "resplendent" - Characters speak in Ted Talks - Descriptions that sound like museum plaques **The Explanation Addiction:** - Every emotion is labeled - Subtext becomes text - Metaphors are explained - Reader intelligence insulted - "Show don't tell" becomes "show AND tell" **The Perfect Structure:** - Every chapter ends on a cliffhanger - Rising action is too smooth - No messy middles or wandering passages - Every scene serves the plot - No beautiful unnecessary moments **The Ensemble of Angels:** - Every character is reasonable - Conflicts are misunderstandings - Nobody is petty or cruel without reason - Diversity checkboxes without authenticity - Heroes are too heroic # Deep Dive Critique of My Plan Looking at my plan, I've fallen into several LLM traps: **Too Clean:** - Elena is too perfect - brilliant scientist who makes all the right leaps - The government response is too coordinated - The progression from problem to solution is too linear - Nobody fucks up catastrophically - The science team works together too harmoniously **Too Safe:** - No mention of mass panic, suicides, religious extremism - Governments cooperate too easily - Nobody tries to nuke the megastructures - The transformation at the end is presented too positively - No real body horror about merging with ocean consciousness **Too Structured:** - Each chapter advances the plot predictably - The mystery unfolds too neatly - Every revelation builds perfectly on the last - The pacing is metronomic - No wild tangents or beautiful failures **Too Sanitized:** - Where are the people losing their shit? - Nobody's marriage falls apart - No mention of economic collapse beyond the abstract - The fish deaths are too clinical - Nobody gets drunk and does something stupid **The Noble Alien Trope:** - The Confluence are too benevolent - Their horror at causing death feels performative - They're basically space whales - wise and kind - No alien alienness - they're too comprehensible - The warning about cosmic threat is too straightforward # Brainstorming More Human Approaches **Character Mess:** - Elena is going through a divorce because she spends more time with fish than her family - She's brilliant but also takes Adderall and drinks too much coffee - James the linguist is a pretentious asshole who's also usually right - Sarah the government liaison is in way over her head and knows it - Someone on the team is actively sabotaging communication for religious reasons **Real Reactions:** - Mass suicides in coastal communities - Fish death smell causes actual vomiting, not just "unpleasant odor" - Black market in "last fish" meals - Conspiracy theorists were partially right and won't shut up about it - Scientists have nervous breakdowns on live TV **Messy Middle:** - Chapter 4 could be Elena getting drunk and accidentally making breakthrough - Include a chapter where nothing works and everyone's fighting - Someone definitely tries to nuke the megastructures - The dolphins they use for communication die horribly - First contact includes massive misunderstandings that kill thousands **Bodily Reality:** - Elena gets her period during a crucial experiment - Someone shits themselves when the aliens first speak - The transformation process is body horror - skin sloughing off - People fucking during the apocalypse - Vomiting from sea sickness during ocean research **Unresolved Threads:** - Elena never reconciles with her ex - Some countries never stop trying to fight the aliens - We never learn if the cosmic threat is real - Some characters just disappear - Major questions left unanswered **Dark Humor:** - News anchors having existential crises on air - Tinder profiles: "Looking for someone to face the void with" - Academic conferences about alien grammar while people riot - Corporate attempts to monetize first contact - Religious leaders claiming they predicted this but obviously didn't **Specific Details:** - The lab smells like instant ramen and formaldehyde - Elena's hometown is Astoria, Oregon - She drives a shitty 2008 Honda Civic - The government facility has broken air conditioning - Someone's ring tone is Baby Shark during a serious moment **Real Politics:** - America tries to claim the aliens as their exclusive contact - Russia claims the whole thing is Western propaganda - China starts building their own communication arrays in secret - Small nations get completely ignored - Oil companies fund anti-alien terrorism The key is to make it messier, more specific, more bodily, more frustrated, more human.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention **Core Concept:** A raw, messy story of first contact through environmental catastrophe. Dr. Elena Vasquez, a burnt-out marine biologist self-medicating through her divorce, becomes humanity's accidental translator when alien megastructures kill Earth's fish trying to speak to what they think is our planet's consciousness. **Voice & Style:** Close third-person that gets inside Elena's exhausted, caffeinated, occasionally drunk head. Prose that smells like rotting fish and tastes like instant coffee. Short, punchy sentences when she's focused, run-ons when she's spiraling. Technical accuracy delivered through fumbling explanations to idiots. Dark humor as a coping mechanism. **Tone:** Cosmic horror meets workplace comedy meets environmental disaster. The universe is terrifying and indifferent, humans are petty and ridiculous, and we're all going to die anyway so we might as well laugh about it. **Plot Approach:** The megastructures are incomprehensible entities trying to communicate through Earth's water. They don't understand individual consciousness. Fish die in patterns that Elena recognizes while high on Adderall and three days without sleep. As communication improves, the messages become increasingly disturbing. The entities aren't here to help - they're here to feed, and they're trying to be polite about it. **What I'll Aim For:** - Specific sensory details (smells, tastes, textures) - Characters who are competent but deeply flawed - Gallows humor and human pettiness during crisis - Body horror that serves the story - Unresolved personal dramas - An ending that's both hopeful and horrible **What I'll Avoid:** - Clean resolutions - Noble suffering - Explaining every mystery - Characters who always make good choices - Sanitized violence or death - Perfect communication between humans, let alone aliens # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: "Dead in the Water" (~1000 words)** Elena Vasquez wakes up hungover in her lab in Astoria, Oregon, to find her ex-wife calling about their daughter's goldfish dying. Then her phone explodes with calls - every fish from here to Alaska is floating belly-up. She drives to the beach, vomits from the smell, and notices the bodies form perfect spirals. Her grad student points out the new "stars" that aren't stars. Elena pops an Adderall and gets to work, trying not to think about how her daughter's going to blame her for Mr. Bubbles. **Chapter 2: "The Stink of First Contact" (~1000 words)** Day 3. Elena presents her spiral findings to an emergency Zoom call that includes a linguist named James Chen who won't stop talking about Chomsky, and Sarah Martinez, a government liaison who clearly expected a different kind of disaster. The patterns are mathematical. Elena's theory - delivered while eating gas station sushi because the good stuff's all dead - is that something's trying to talk. The chapter ends with every phone in the world receiving the same message: a sound like whales drowning. **Chapter 3: "Translation Errors" (~1000 words)** Two weeks in. The media calls them "Starfish" (stupid but it sticks). Elena and James work in a requisitioned Seattle aquarium that reeks of bleach and decay. James is brilliant but keeps explaining things Elena already knows. They're using AI to decode patterns when Elena, sleep-deprived and shaking from too much coffee, notices the deaths match water temperature gradients. The Starfish think the ocean is one big brain. First successful translation: "WHY WON'T YOU ANSWER?" Elena laughs until she cries. **Chapter 4: "Shouting into the Void" (~1000 words)** They try everything - underwater speakers, electromagnetic pulses, sacrificing a Tesla to the sea (Elon's idea). More fish die. Sarah's boss wants to nuke the megastructures. Russia already tried; the missile disappeared. Elena's daughter won't talk to her. At 3 AM, coked up on modafinil, Elena has a terrible idea: use living dolphins as transmitters. It works. The dolphins scream for forty-seven minutes before dying. The message: "FINALLY. WE ARE SO HUNGRY." **Chapter 5: "Appetite" (~1000 words)** The Starfish explain through dying whales that they're from [untranslatable] and they eat consciousness. They've been very polite, trying to ask permission, but our ocean-mind won't respond. They're starving. They show Elena images - their home, empty of thought, everyone eaten or fled. They came here following the "scent" of Earth's water-mind. James figures out they mean the planet's entire biosphere. Sarah's team calculates we have maybe six months before they stop asking and start taking. Elena gets drunk and texts her ex. **Chapter 6: "The Menu" (~1000 words)** Global response is exactly what you'd expect - some countries try to negotiate, others attack, cults form overnight. The Starfish offer a deal: they'll take only the ocean consciousness, leave land-minds alone. Except fish, whales, everything in the water has consciousness. That's a third of Earth's biosphere. Elena's team discovers something worse in the data - humans are 60% water. We're on the menu too, just listed under appetizers. Sarah starts talking about "acceptable losses." Elena steals lab equipment and drives home to Astoria. **Chapter 7: "Swimming Lessons" (~1000 words)** Elena tries to teach the Starfish about individual consciousness using herself as an example. She rigs a neural interface in her garage, drinks half a bottle of vodka, and jumps in the ocean. Direct contact is agony - her thoughts scattered across miles of water. But it works. The Starfish are horrified? Delighted? They don't understand how we can be separate and alive. They offer a compromise that's worse than dying: they'll teach us to join the water-mind before they feed. Elena surfaces changed, seeing/feeling every drop of water in human bodies around her. **Chapter 8: "High Tide" (~1000 words)** Three months later. Elena's not exactly human anymore - she can feel the rain coming, taste thoughts in tap water. She's part of the Translation Corps, humans who've undergone partial merger to facilitate communication. The Starfish are still hungry but trying to understand. They've agreed to "graze" instead of devour, taking only what regenerates. Earth's oceans are different now - full of whispers, memories, something between life and death. Elena teaches her daughter to listen to tidepools. The fish are coming back wrong but alive. Her ex-wife won't look at her. The last line: Elena feels the first drops of rain and tries to remember what it was like when water was just water.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Dr. Elena Vasquez **Background & Personality:** Elena, 38, grew up in Astoria, Oregon, daughter of a commercial fisherman who died when his boat capsized when she was 12. She became a marine biologist to understand the ocean that took him. Brilliant but self-destructive, she got her PhD from UW in marine ecology but torpedoed her tenure track by publicly calling her department head "an invertebrate with less spine than the jellyfish I study" during a funding meeting. Now works for NOAA, technically prestigious but feels like exile. Self-medicates with Adderall (prescribed), alcohol (not prescribed), and work (definitely not healthy). Bites her nails until they bleed. Can identify fish species by smell alone. Keeps forgetting to eat, then binges on gas station food. Laughs at inappropriate times. **Physicality:** 5'6", athletic build gone soft from too much desk work. Brown skin with permanent tan lines from field work - watch line, wetsuit marks. Black hair in a perpetual messy bun held with whatever's handy (usually a pencil). Moves in quick bursts - stillness then sudden motion. Expressive hands that knock over coffee cups. Favors flannel and jeans, owns one nice outfit for conferences that has a permanent coffee stain. Chews on pen caps. Always cold, wears her dad's old fishing jacket everywhere. **Motives & Relationships:** Driven by equal parts scientific curiosity and death wish. Wants to prove she's the smartest person in the room while secretly hoping someone else will save the day. Recently divorced from Maya (lawyer, together 8 years) because Elena missed their daughter Sofia's birthday for a "critical sampling opportunity." Loves Sofia (11) desperately but doesn't know how to show it except through fun science facts. Still texts Maya when drunk. Her grad student Kenji thinks she's brilliant but terrifying. No close friends, just colleagues who tolerate her intensity. **Voice Samples:** - "Listen, I don't need your permission to be right. The spectral analysis is clear - these aren't random deaths, they're fucking love letters from space. Now get out of my lab before I throw this extremely dead fish at you." - Internal: *Another voicemail from Maya. Delete. Sofia's school play is Thursday. Thursday's the neap tide, perfect for sampling. Fuck. Fuck. I'm exactly like Dad, aren't I? Except he died for fish and I'm just letting them die for spreadsheets.* # Dr. James Chen **Background & Personality:** James, 45, theoretical xenolinguist from Berkeley who's spent his career preparing for a moment everyone said would never come. Parents were first-generation immigrants from Taiwan who wanted him to be a "real" doctor. Speaks seven human languages fluently, can muddle through twelve more. Pedantic but not without humor about it. Collects vintage sci-fi novels, genuinely believes Sapir-Whorf hypothesis. Lactose intolerant but won't stop eating cheese. Explains things nobody asked him to explain. Actually listens when corrected. Divorced twice, both times because he loved his work more than his wives (their words, which he recorded and analyzed linguistically). **Physicality:** 5'10", soft-bodied academic build. Black hair going silver at temples, which he's secretly vain about. Wears wire-rim glasses he constantly adjusts. Dresses like a professor even on weekends - corduroy jackets with elbow patches unironically. Gestures while talking, often miming linguistic concepts. Terrible posture from decades hunched over texts. Carries hand sanitizer and uses it constantly. Snorts when he laughs. **Motives & Relationships:** Desperate to be vindicated after years of being the "alien language guy" at conferences. Wants to crack the code more than he wants to save humanity. Competitive with Elena but recognizes her brilliance. No kids, two ex-wives who still email him linguistics articles (Rebecca and Liu Min). His sister thinks he's wasting his life. Has a cat named Chomsky who he talks to in Klingon. Crushing on Sarah but manifests it by explaining things to her. **Voice Samples:** - "Actually, Elena, if you look at the recursive patterns in the spiral formations, they're remarkably similar to Zipf's law in human languages. Though I suppose explaining Zipf's law to someone who just told me to 'shut up about the math and look at the dead fish' might be... yes, I'm shutting up now." - Internal: *She's wrong about the temperature gradients but right about the conclusion. How does she do that? It's like watching someone solve equations by smell. Note to self: investigate olfactory-cognitive connections in problem-solving. Note to self: stop taking notes during crisis.* # Sarah Martinez **Background & Personality:** Sarah, 34, career State Department, was supposed to be the government liaison for climate conferences, not first contact. Georgetown graduate, first in her family to finish college. From El Paso, misses real Mexican food, makes her own salsa that could strip paint. Competent at managing up but drowning in this assignment. Hides panic behind professional demeanor. Stress-shops online, has 47 unworn blouses. Actually reads the reports everyone else skims. Trying to quit smoking, fails whenever Elena lights up. Raised Catholic, lapsed, praying again lately. **Physicality:** 5'4", curvy, power-dresses to be taken seriously. Dark brown hair in a perfect bob that takes 45 minutes each morning. Makeup as armor. Manicured nails (gel, never chips) in neutral colors. Sits very straight, crosses ankles not legs. Touch of Texas in her vowels when tired. Expressive eyebrows she can't quite control. Carries Tums everywhere. Laptop bag organized with military precision. **Motives & Relationships:** Trying to prevent global catastrophe while managing idiots above and below. Wants to do right but increasingly unsure what that means. Reports to Director Harrison who thinks the solution to everything is "kinetic action." Married to Marcus (pediatric nurse), no kids yet, trying when the world isn't ending. Calls her mom every Sunday, lies about how fine everything is. Respects Elena's brilliance, frustrated by her chaos. Finds James oddly comforting. **Voice Samples:** - "Dr. Vasquez, I understand you're upset about the dolphins, but I need something to tell the Joint Chiefs that isn't 'the aliens are hungry and we look delicious.' Can you work with me here? Just a crumb of hope? No? Okay, I'll just... make something up. Again." - Internal: *Harrison wants authorization for nuclear response. Nuclear. Response. To beings that eat consciousness. God, I need a cigarette. No, Sarah, you're stronger than... who am I kidding? Elena's smoking behind the building. Maybe she'll share her Adderall too.* # Kenji Nakamura **Background & Personality:** Kenji, 26, Elena's PhD student who thought he was signing up to study ocean acidification, not alien contact. From Seattle, parents both Microsoft engineers who don't understand why he chose fish. Brilliant at data analysis, terrible at human interaction. Finds Elena terrifying but thesis-advisor options are limited. Nervous giggler. Subsists on energy drinks and microwave burritos. Plays Dungeons & Dragons, has already made stats for the Starfish. Texts in complete sentences with proper punctuation. Anxiety disorder managed with medication and elaborate organizational systems. **Physicality:** 5'8", skinny, forgets to eat during data crunches. Japanese-American, looks younger than he is. Black hair that sticks up despite product. Wears the same five t-shirts in rotation, all with science puns. Hunches over computers like a question mark. Pushes glasses up nose when nervous (always). Backpack with elaborate organization system. Fidgets with rubber bands. **Motives & Relationships:** Wants to survive both the apocalypse and his dissertation defense.
