The tapping at the window and the buzzing phone create genuine unease without overplaying the horror elements. Overall, this chapter succeeds in capturing the specific YA British voice intended, balancing humor with genuine anxiety, and portraying a teenager's desperate attempt to maintain normalcy when faced with the inexplicable. The writing is confident in its style and pacing, creating a chapter that advances the plot while developing character. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 5: The Car Park Revelation Friday morning and my perfect bubble of denial pops the second I check my phone. 47 missed calls from Dad. FORTY-SEVEN. Who does that? Serial killers and desperate exes, that's who. Plus twelve texts that escalate from "please call me" to "MAISIE ANSWER YOUR BLOODY PHONE" to just "?????????" I'm reading them on the toilet because that's where I make all my bad decisions, when Mum knocks. "Maisie? Your dad's here." "What?" I nearly drop my phone in the bowl. "Here here?" "Downstairs here. Says it's urgent." Dad doesn't come to the house. It's like, rule number one of divorced parents. His territory is sad flat in Croydon and Costa. Our territory is here. Neutral ground is car parks and school events where they pretend to be civil. I find him in the kitchen looking properly rough. Stubble, same clothes as yesterday probably, coffee stain on his Joy Division t-shirt that he thinks makes him look cool but just makes him look forty-three. "Jesus, Maisie, I thought—" He stops when he sees Mum. "Sarah. You look well." "Marcus." She's doing her ice queen voice. "Bit early for a social call." "It's not social." He turns back to me. "Maisie, we need to talk. Now." "She's got school," Mum says. "She's coming with me," Dad says. "I don't think so." "Sarah, please. This is important." They're doing that thing where they have an entire argument with just their eyes. I'm standing there in my school uniform feeling like I'm five again, watching them fight about custody arrangements. "I've got Biology," I say, which is true but also the least of my problems. "Fuck Biology," Dad says, then catches Mum's death glare. "Sorry. But this is life or death." "Don't be dramatic," Mum says. "I'm not being—" He stops. Takes a breath. "Twenty minutes. Just give me twenty minutes to explain. Then she can decide." Mum looks at me. I shrug. Might as well get this over with. "Fine," she says. "Twenty minutes. And she's taking her phone." "Actually maybe she shouldn't—" "She's taking her phone, Marcus." We end up in Costa because of course we do. Dad orders two coffees and a pain au chocolat I didn't ask for but definitely want. We sit in the corner, away from the mums with pushchairs and people pretending to work on laptops. "Right," he says. "How much do you know about my family?" "Uh. Grandad died before I was born. Grandma sends cards sometimes. You've got a sister in Canada who doesn't talk to you." "Do you know why she doesn't talk to me?" "Because you borrowed money and never paid it back?" "What? No. Well, yes, but that's not—" He rubs his face. "Christ, this is hard. Okay. Remember when you were little, you asked why my surname was different from other Blackwoods in the phone book?" "You said it was because of tradition." "Right. It is tradition. A really fucking stupid tradition that goes back to Victorian times." He's tearing his napkin into tiny pieces. "The Blackwoods were... are... look, this is going to sound mental." "Dad. Just say it." "Vampire hunters." I stare at him. He stares at his shredded napkin. "Vampire hunters," I repeat. "Yeah." "Like... Buffy?" "No, not like—well, a bit like Buffy. But boring. More admin than fighting. Keeping records, monitoring populations, maintaining truces." "Dad, are you having a breakdown?" "I wish." He laughs but it's not a happy sound. "Look, I know how it sounds. When I was your age, Grandad sat me down and told me the same thing. I laughed in his face. Took me seeing one to believe it." "Seeing a vampire." "Yeah. Mrs. Patterson from number forty-two. Lovely woman. Made amazing Victoria sponge. Also been dead since 1963." I think about Mrs. Ashworth and her seventeen black puddings. About Mr. Vance and his vitamin D deficiency. About the tapping at my window. "The blood drops," I say quietly. "Old protocol. Three drops means you've been marked for assessment. Two means they're watching. One means—" "Tomorrow night. Be ready." He goes very still. "You got a text." "Yeah." "Shit." He's up, pacing now. Other customers are staring. "Okay. Okay. This is manageable. You just need to survive tomorrow night. Sunrise to sunset. Then they leave you alone for another generation." "What happens tomorrow night?" "Test. They test if you're going to follow family tradition. Hunt them. But here's the thing – you can fail. I failed. Told them to piss off, went to uni, formed a band. Thought I'd escaped." "But?" "But then I met your mum. Had you. And suddenly there's another generation for them to bother." He sits back down. "I left to protect you. Thought if I wasn't around, they'd skip you. Go straight to your kids." "I'm sixteen." "Yeah, well. Vampires are optimistic about timelines." This is insane. My dad's having a breakdown about vampires and I'm missing Biology. But then I think about the History test. How I wrote two pages about vampires without meaning to. How Mr. Vance knew about the three drops. How Derek told me to call in sick. "Holy shit," I say. "It's real." "Language," Dad says automatically. "But yes. Real. Not everywhere, not loads of them. But enough. And they've got rules. Protocols. Can't enter homes uninvited. Can't turn anyone without consent. Can't hunt humans who haven't hunted them first." "So if I just... don't hunt them?" "Then after tomorrow night, they leave you alone. Mostly. You'll see them around – shops, schools, whatever. But they'll ignore you. You'll be marked as 'declined' in their records." "Records?" "They're very bureaucratic. Victorian influence. Love a good ledger." My phone buzzes. Priya: "where are you??? peterson asking about you" "I need to go to school," I say. "Maisie, this is serious." "So are my GCSEs." I stand up. "Look, thanks for the warning. I'll stay inside tomorrow night. Won't invite anyone in. Job done." "It's not that simple—" "It is though. You said you failed. You're fine. Bit weird, but fine. I'll fail too. Go back to normal life." He looks like he wants to argue but I'm already leaving. Got Biology to fail, friends to lie to, a normal life to protect. Outside Costa, the world looks exactly the same. People shopping, cars parking badly, pigeons fighting over chips. Hard to believe there are vampires in the mix. But then I see her – Mrs. Ashworth, coming out of Boots with a Meal Deal. She sees me, waves with her free hand. I wave back because what else do you do when a vampire acknowledges you in broad daylight? Dad comes out behind me. Sees her. Goes pale. "Victoria," he says. "Marcus." She nods politely. "Your daughter, I presume? She served me at Sainsbury's. Lovely girl. Terrible at her job, but lovely." "Thanks?" I say. "You'll do fine tomorrow," she tells me. "The young ones always overthink it. Just remember – sunrise to sunset, no invitations, and try not to bleed. The smell is terribly distracting." She walks off, heels clicking on pavement, Meal Deal swinging from one manicured hand. "That was a vampire," I say. "With a Tesco Meal Deal." "Marks and Spencer, actually. She's got standards." Dad's trying to joke but his hands are shaking. "Maisie, please. Let me help with tomorrow." "I'm good. Honestly. I'll lock myself in my room, watch Netflix, wait it out. Easy." "But—" "Dad. I'm going to school now. Thanks for the coffee and the life-changing revelation about our family's vampire hunting legacy. Really appreciate it. But I've got Biology." I leave him standing outside Costa looking lost. Feel a bit bad about it. Not bad enough to go back though. School's already started so I have to sign in late. The receptionist gives me a look but doesn't ask questions. Probably assumes I was at the dentist again. Slip into Biology just as Peterson's explaining something about enzymes. He pauses, looks at me over his glasses. "Nice of you to join us, Maisie. Family emergency sorted?" "Yeah. All good." I sit next to Priya who whispers, "What the fuck?" "Tell you later," I whisper back. But I won't. Can't. How do you tell your best friend that vampires are real and you're apparently from a long line of people who hunt them? You don't. You keep it secret and hope she never finds out. Peterson drones on about digestive enzymes. I try to focus but my mind keeps drifting. Tomorrow night. Sunrise to sunset. Don't invite anyone in. Don't bleed. How hard can it be? My phone buzzes. Unknown number. I don't need to look to know what it says. One blood drop. One more day.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully delivers the pivotal "car park revelation" moment where Maisie learns about her family's vampire hunting legacy. The writing maintains a consistent voice throughout, capturing the British YA dark comedy tone with Maisie's sardonic internal monologue and the awkward family dynamics. The chapter follows the planned structure well, hitting all the key plot points: Dad's appearance, the Costa meeting, the explanation of the family vampire hunting tradition, and the encounter with Victoria Ashworth. The three-blood-drops protocol is explained clearly, establishing the stakes for the coming night. Character-wise, Maisie's voice is authentic and consistent with her profile - she's sarcastic, slightly self-absorbed, and deflects serious situations with humor. Her priorities (like worrying about Biology class amid vampire revelations) feel true to a 16-year-old. Dad comes across exactly as described in his profile: well-meaning but slightly pathetic, trying too hard to connect with his daughter. The brief appearance of Victoria Ashworth perfectly captures her bureaucratic vampire personality. The dialogue is one of the strongest elements, particularly the strained conversation between Maisie's parents. The short, clipped exchanges reveal their history without exposition. Dad's fumbling explanation of vampire hunting feels authentic - he's not a smooth expositor but a nervous father trying to protect his daughter. The chapter balances humor and tension effectively. Moments like Victoria Ashworth with her M&S meal deal provide comic relief while maintaining the underlying threat. The writing avoids purple prose and forced metaphors, instead relying on Maisie's authentic teenage voice. There are a few minor weaknesses. Some of the exposition about vampire rules feels slightly info-dumpy, though it's mitigated by being delivered through Dad's awkward explanation. The chapter could have delved deeper into Maisie's emotional reaction to this life-changing revelation - her acceptance comes perhaps a bit too quickly, though her deflection through focusing on school is consistent with her character. The chapter ends with appropriate tension - the one blood drop text creates anticipation for the coming night while Maisie's false confidence ("How hard can it be?") sets up dramatic irony for readers. Overall, this is a strong chapter that successfully blends British humor, teenage angst, and supernatural elements while advancing the plot and developing the characters in line with their established profiles. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 18 Coherent: 19 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 6: Friday Night, Saturday Morning Friday night I'm in my room with enough supplies to survive a nuclear war. Crisps, biscuits, those little cheese triangles that don't need refrigerating, six cans of Coke, and a bucket I really hope I won't need. Mum thinks I've got food poisoning. "You sure you don't want me to stay home tomorrow?" she calls through the door. "I'm fine. Just dodgy chicken." I had to make retching sounds earlier to sell it. Academy Award worthy performance. "Text if you need anything." "Will do." I hear her go to bed at ten. Early for a Friday but she's got her book club tomorrow. They read one chapter then drink three bottles of wine. Good for her honestly. I've pushed my desk against the door again. Window's locked, curtains drawn, even put tape around the edges like I'm trying to keep out a draft. Which I suppose I am. A vampire-shaped draft. 11:47 PM according to my phone. Thirteen minutes until Saturday. Thirteen minutes until I need to not die for twelve hours. I could sleep. Should sleep probably. But every time I close my eyes I see Mrs. Ashworth's too-many teeth or imagine something scratching at the window. So instead I'm rewatching The Office (US because I'm basic) and trying not to think. My phone buzzes. Priya: "you alive? you were weird today" I want to reply. Want to tell her everything. Instead I send back: "yeah food poisoning. Grim" "Ew. Want me to bring you anything tmrw?" "Nah I'm good. Probably contagious" "K. Feel better x" She sends a vomit emoji and three hearts. I send back a thumbs up because I'm terrible at emotions even in emoji form. Midnight comes and goes. Nothing happens. No dramatic thunder. No bats at the window. Just Jim looking at the camera like we're sharing a private joke. Maybe this will be easy. Maybe vampires are lazy on Saturdays like everyone else. 2 AM. Still nothing. I've eaten half the crisps and need a wee but I'm not leaving this room. The bucket's looking more appealing which is a sentence I never thought I'd think. 2:17 AM. Scratching at the window. My whole body goes cold. It's light, almost polite. Like someone knocking gently because they don't want to wake the neighbours. I turn the laptop volume up. Dwight's talking about beets. The scratching continues. "Maisie?" Voice from outside. Young, male, nervous. "I know you're awake. I can hear Netflix." I pause The Office. Mistake. Now I can hear everything. The scratching, his breathing (do vampires breathe?), my own heartbeat going mental. "I'm not going to hurt you," he continues. "I'm supposed to do this whole threatening thing but honestly I'm terrible at it. I just need to ask the questions and then I can leave." Questions. Dad didn't mention questions. "You're not invited in," I say, voice embarrassingly squeaky. "I know. That's fine. I don't need to come in. Can we just talk? Through the window? Makes my job easier." "What job?" "Assessment. I'm supposed to assess if you're a threat. Which, no offense, but you're watching The Office in your pyjamas so I'm thinking probably not." How does he know about my pyjamas? Oh god, can he see through curtains? I pull my duvet up higher. "I can't see through curtains," he says like he's reading my mind. "But you were wearing Totoro pyjamas at 11:15 when you looked outside." Fuck. I did look. Just for a second. Just to check. "Look, I'm really bad at this," he continues. "This is my first assessment. I'm supposed to be all mysterious and threatening but I threw up earlier from nerves. Blood doesn't agree with me when I'm anxious." Despite everything, I nearly laugh. "You're a vampire who can't handle blood?" "It's a texture thing. Anyway, can I just ask the questions? Then we can both pretend this went normally." This is insane. I'm having a conversation with an anxious vampire through my bedroom window at 2 AM. "What questions?" "Right. Yes. Questions." He clears his throat. "Do you, Maisie Chen-Blackwood, descendant of the Blackwood line, intend to pursue your hereditary role as a vampire hunter?" "No." "Brilliant. Second question: Do you possess any artifacts, weapons, or knowledge that could be used against the vampire community?" "I don't think so?" "Good enough. Final question: Will you maintain the Covenant of Mutual Ignorance established in 1847?" "The what now?" "Basically, we pretend you don't know about us, you pretend we don't exist, everyone goes about their business." "Yeah, fine. Whatever." "Excellent." He sounds genuinely relieved. "Right, that's me done. I'll file the report as 'Declined - Non-Threat' and you'll be left alone. Mostly. You might see us around but we won't bother you." "That's it?" "That's it. Bit anticlimactic, sorry. Gary - he's my mentor - he says it used to be much more dramatic. Proper fights, stakes through hearts, very Hammer Horror. But then health and safety got involved and now it's mostly paperwork." "Health and safety for vampires?" "You'd be surprised. Anyway, sunrise is at 6:47 so you've got about four hours left. Some of the others might try their luck but just don't invite them in and you'll be fine." "Others?" "Yeah, not everyone agrees with the new protocols. Some of the older ones think we should still do things properly. All ceremony and blood oaths. But between you and me, they mostly just complain on the Facebook group and do nothing about it." "Vampires have a Facebook group?" "Several. The drama is incredible. You think your aunt's political posts are bad? Try centuries-old beings arguing about parking spaces." I actually do laugh at that. Can't help it. "Anyway," he says. "Good luck with the rest. Oh, and Maisie? Maybe don't mention I was sick. Gary's already disappointed in me." "Your secret's safe." "Thanks. Right. Off I go then. Nice not really meeting you." I hear footsteps walking away. Then running. Then a thud and swearing. "I'm okay!" he calls out. "Just... forgot about the recycling bins. Bye!" And he's gone. My first vampire encounter and it was with someone who sounds like he'd fit right in with my anxiety-ridden generation. 3 AM. 4 AM. More scratching, but I ignore it. Someone tries the old "let me in I'm hurt" routine but they give up when I don't respond. Another one spends twenty minutes listing all the ways they could kill me if they were allowed, but they sound bored, like they're reading from a script. 5:30 AM. I really need to wee. The bucket's looking inevitable. 6:00 AM. I use the bucket. We don't talk about it. 6:30 AM. The sky's getting lighter. Seventeen minutes until sunrise. I've survived. Mostly. Bit smelly and definitely traumatized but alive. 6:45 AM. Two minutes to go. I'm watching the clock on my phone, willing it to move faster. 6:46 AM. One minute. Someone knocks on my bedroom door. From inside the house. My blood turns to ice. How did they— "Maisie?" Mum's voice. "You okay in there? Thought I heard voices." "Fine!" My voice cracks. "Just. YouTube!" "At six in the morning?" "Couldn't sleep!" She tries the door handle. Finds it blocked. "Why's your desk against the door?" "I... dropped something behind it?" "Maisie, open this door right now." I look at my phone. 6:47. Sunrise. I'm safe. I move the desk, open the door. Mum's standing there in her dressing gown, looking concerned and annoyed in equal measure. "What's going on? And what's that smell?" "Food poisoning?" I try. She looks past me at the chaos of my room. The taped windows. The empty crisp packets. The bucket I've tried to hide under my desk. "Right," she says. "Shower. Now. Then you're telling me exactly what's happening." "But—" "Now, Maisie." I grab clean clothes and escape to the bathroom. In the mirror I look properly mental. Hair everywhere, dark circles, bit of crisp in my eyebrow somehow. But I survived. Declined my vampire hunting heritage while watching The Office and weeing in a bucket. Not exactly heroic but it worked. My phone buzzes. Unknown number. "Assessment complete. Status: Declined. Have a normal life, Maisie Blackwood." Then, a second later, from the same number: "P.S. - Jim and Pam are better than Ross and Rachel. Fight me. - Nigel" I save the number as "Anxious Vampire" and go have the world's longest shower. Normal life, here I come.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully captures the darkly comic British YA tone established in the prompt and writing plan. The author has created a genuinely entertaining scenario where the supernatural threat is undercut by bureaucracy, anxiety, and mundane concerns - a perfect balance for the genre. The chapter follows Maisie's night of vampire-proofing her room, which culminates not in a terrifying confrontation but in an awkward conversation with an equally anxious vampire named Nigel who's just trying to complete his paperwork. This subversion works well, maintaining tension while introducing humor. Character-wise, Maisie feels authentic as a British teenager - her internal monologue, text exchanges with Priya, and interactions with her mother all ring true. The author has maintained her established character traits: making inappropriate jokes, being terrible at lying, and using humor to deflect from fear. Her voice is consistent throughout, with lines like "I use the bucket. We don't talk about it" perfectly capturing teenage mortification. The introduction of Nigel, the anxious vampire, is a creative addition that wasn't explicitly mentioned in the character profiles but fits perfectly with the tone. His nervousness about his job performance and admission that "blood doesn't agree with me when I'm anxious" creates an unexpected connection between him and Maisie. Dialogue is a particular strength. The exchanges between Maisie and Nigel feel natural and reveal character while advancing the plot. The revelation about vampire Facebook groups and health and safety regulations is both funny and worldbuilding. Maisie's terrible lies to her mother ("I dropped something behind it?") effectively communicate her panic. The chapter follows the plan quite closely, hitting all the major beats: Maisie barricading herself in her room, the scratching at the window becoming knocking, and the revelation that Mr. Vance (though renamed as Nigel) is trying to complete an assessment rather than attack her. The chapter ends with Maisie's mother discovering the aftermath, setting up conflict for the next chapter. There are a few minor weaknesses. The chapter occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when describing Maisie's emotions ("My whole body goes cold"). Some of the humor is a bit on-the-nose, and the vampire bureaucracy angle, while funny, isn't entirely original in contemporary fantasy. Overall, this is a strong chapter that balances humor and tension effectively while maintaining the established voice and advancing the plot in an engaging way. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 7: The Longest Saturday The shower doesn't help. I still look like someone who spent the night fighting off supernatural beings with crisps and American comedy. Mum's waiting in the kitchen with her Serious Face on. "Sit," she says. I sit. "Talk." "About what?" "Maisie Chen-Blackwood, I found a bucket of wee in your room." "Actually, I think you'll find you didn't look in the bucket, so technically—" "MAISIE." Right. No jokes then. "I was ill?" I try. "You barricaded your door and taped your windows shut." "Really ill?" She pinches the bridge of her nose. Classic Mum stress gesture. "Is this drugs? Because if it's drugs, we can get help. There's no shame in—" "It's not drugs!" "Then what? Because your father called six times this morning asking if you were okay, and when I asked why you wouldn't be, he hung up." Of course he did. Absolute muppet. "It's..." I start, then stop. Can't exactly say vampires. "You know Dad's family is a bit weird?" "That's one way of putting it." "Well, they've got this tradition. Like a coming-of-age thing? And I had to do it last night but I didn't want to so I just... hid in my room until it was over." She stares at me. "You hid in your room with a bucket to avoid a family tradition?" "Yeah?" "What kind of tradition requires you to barricade yourself in?" "The really shit kind?" More staring. I can see her processing, trying to decide if I'm lying, on drugs, or having a breakdown. Maybe all three. "Right," she says finally. "Your father's coming over. We're having a family meeting." "Mum, no—" "Yes. Whatever this is, we're dealing with it. Together. Like adults." "I'm not an adult!" "No, you're a teenager who weed in a bucket. We need to talk about your life choices." Dad arrives an hour later looking worse than me, which is impressive. He's got that manic energy of someone who hasn't slept and has had too much coffee. "Is she okay? Did anything happen? I tried to call but—" "Marcus, sit down," Mum says in her teacher voice. He sits. "Someone needs to explain what happened last night, and they need to do it without any of this cryptic nonsense you're both so fond of." Dad and I look at each other. He raises his eyebrows like 'you or me?' I shrug like 'you're the adult here.' "It's about the family business," he says finally. "The vampire hunting," I add, because fuck it. Mum blinks. "The what?" "Vampire hunting. Dad's family. Whole thing. Very Victorian. I declined participation." "By weeing in a bucket," Mum says flatly. "That was incidental." She looks between us. We must look properly mental, sitting here talking about vampires like it's normal. "Show her," I tell Dad. "Show her what?" "I don't know, your vampire hunting license or whatever." "I don't have a— that's not how it works." "Then how does it work?" "It's complicated!" "IT'S REALLY NOT," Mum shouts, which is shocking because Mum never shouts. "Either vampires are real or you're both having synchronized breakdowns. Which is it?" Before either of us can answer, the doorbell rings. We all freeze. "Who's that?" Dad whispers. "How should I know?" Mum snaps, but she looks nervous now. I check my phone. Text from unknown number: "Hi Maisie, it's Victoria Ashworth. I'm at your door with some paperwork. Nothing scary, just bureaucracy. Promise I'm not here to eat anyone." "It's Mrs. Ashworth," I say. "The vampire from Sainsbury's." "The what from where?" Mum asks. "She's nice! Bought loads of black pudding. Has excellent manners." Dad's on his feet. "Don't let her in." "Wasn't planning to." The doorbell rings again. Then knocking. Very polite knocking. "Hello?" Victoria calls through the letterbox. "I can hear you all in there. I just need Maisie to sign some forms. Very boring stuff. I've brought biscuits as an apology for the intrusion." "She brought biscuits," I say. "Don't care," Dad says. "What kind?" Mum asks, then catches herself. "No. Wait. Are we seriously discussing biscuit varieties with someone who claims to be a vampire?" "Chocolate hobnobs," Victoria calls. "The good ones, not own brand." We all consider this. Chocolate hobnobs are quite good. "I'll talk to her through the door," I decide. "Maisie, no—" Dad starts, but I'm already in the hallway. Victoria's silhouette is visible through the frosted glass. She waves. "Hi Mrs. Ashworth," I say through the door. "Maisie, dear. Congratulations on surviving your assessment. Bit dramatic with the bucket from what I heard, but we've all been there." "You heard about the bucket?" "Nigel mentioned it in his report. Don't worry, I've redacted that part. No need for it to be in the official records." "Thanks?" "Now, I need you to sign a D-49 form confirming your declined status, and a B-17 acknowledging you've been informed of your rights under the Covenant." "Can you... slide them through the letterbox?" "Of course. I've also included a pamphlet about living alongside the vampire community. Very informative. Has a FAQ section." Several papers come through the slot, followed by a pen. I gather them up, glancing at the top form. It's incredibly official looking, with a watermark and everything. "This looks like tax paperwork," I say. "Yes, we modeled our bureaucracy on HMRC. Very efficient. Equally soul-destroying." I skim through the forms. It's mostly stuff about agreeing not to hunt vampires, not to reveal their existence to non-aware humans, not to sell their secrets to Netflix. "There's a section here about Netflix?" "Oh yes. After that awful Dracula adaptation, we had to add specific clauses. Some of our younger members were quite upset about the portrayal." I sign where indicated, trying not to think too hard about the fact I'm entering into a legal contract with vampires. "All done," I say, sliding the papers back. "Excellent. Oh, and Maisie? Your shift at Sainsbury's is covered tonight. Derek's been informed you're still unwell." "Derek knows about vampires?" "Derek knows about sick leave. Different thing entirely. Though between you and me, he's been very helpful about scheduling conflicts during full moons." "That's werewolves." "Common misconception. We just have a very active book club that meets monthly. Anyway, must dash. Sainsbury's has a sale on black pudding and I want to stock up before the rush." Her footsteps retreat down the path. I stand there holding the pamphlet: "So You've Discovered Vampires: A Guide to Coexistence." When I get back to the kitchen, Mum and Dad are sitting in silence. I put the pamphlet on the table. Mum picks it up, reads the title, puts it down. Picks it up again. "Vampires," she says. "Vampires," I confirm. "In Ealing." "Apparently everywhere, but yes." "And you've known about this how long?" She turns to Dad. "Since I was sixteen. But I tried to keep you both out of it. That's why I left. Thought it would protect you." "You left to protect us from vampires?" "Among other things." "What other things?" "Well, there was also that thing with the band and the—" "MARCUS." They start arguing. Not about vampires, weirdly, but about communication and trust and who was supposed to pick me up from swimming lessons in Year 4. Standard divorced parent stuff, just with added supernatural elements. I text Priya: "parents being weird. might be late tonight" She texts back immediately: "everything ok???" "yeah just family drama" "want me to come over?" "NO" I type, then delete it. Type: "nah I'm good. see you later?" "park at 8? bringing jade and marcus" "cool" Normal plans with normal friends. That's what I need after last night. Even if I'm now legally bound not to tell them about vampires. "I'm going out later," I announce. Mum and Dad stop mid-argument. "Out?" Dad says. "But what if—" "The assessment's over. I declined. I'm officially not a vampire hunter. So I'm going to the park with my friends like a normal person." "But—" "No buts. I spent last night in my room with a bucket. I survived. I signed the forms. I'm done with vampire stuff." "It's not that simple—" Dad starts. "It really is though." I'm surprised to find I'm angry. Properly angry. "You left us to protect us from this but didn't tell us what we were being protected from. Mum's just finding out the man she married hunts vampires. I had to wee in a bucket. So yeah, I'm going out tonight. I'm going to pretend none of this happened. And you two can sort out whatever this is without me." I leave them in the kitchen and go back to my room. It still smells a bit but at least the sun's out. I open the windows, rip down the tape, put my desk back where it belongs. My phone buzzes. Nigel: "Sorry about the bucket thing being in the report. Gary made me include it for completeness. Hope your mum wasn't too mad." I text back: "she's more mad about the vampires tbh" "Fair. Parents are weird about that stuff. Mine still introduce me as 'our son, the vampire' like it's my whole personality." "that sucks" "Literally lol. Anyway, glad you survived. Welcome to the weird middle ground between normal and supernatural." "thanks I hate it" He sends back a laughing emoji and a vampire emoji I didn't even know existed. I lie on my bed and try to process the last 24 hours. Yesterday morning I was worried about Biology. Now I'm legally recognized as a non-threat by the vampire community. Character development, I guess. From downstairs, I can hear Mum and Dad still talking. Not arguing anymore, just talking. Probably trying to figure out custody arrangements for a daughter who knows about vampires. My normal life is officially over. But looking at the pamphlet on my bedside table, at Nigel's texts, at the sun streaming through my untaped windows, I realize something. Maybe it was never that normal to begin with.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully captures the darkly comic British YA tone established in the prompt and writing plan. The author has created a chapter that balances supernatural elements with mundane teenage concerns, using Maisie's distinctive voice to navigate both worlds. The chapter follows the planned structure of "The Longest Saturday" quite well, though with some modifications. We see the aftermath of Maisie's night barricaded in her room, the confrontation with her mother, the arrival of her father, and the unexpected visit from Victoria Ashworth. The bureaucratic approach to vampirism is a clever subversion of typical vampire tropes, making the supernatural elements both more believable and more humorous. Maisie's character is consistent with her profile - she makes inappropriate jokes when nervous ("Actually, I think you'll find you didn't look in the bucket, so technically—"), uses British slang naturally ("Absolute muppet"), and maintains her self-centered teenage perspective while still showing growth. Her relationship with her parents feels authentic, with the right mix of exasperation and underlying affection. The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character having a distinct voice. Victoria Ashworth's polite bureaucratic vampire is delightful, and the contrast between her formal manner and the absurdity of the situation creates effective humor. The family dynamics between Maisie, her mother, and father feel genuine, with their conversation revealing long-standing tensions beyond the immediate vampire situation. The chapter does an excellent job of integrating text messages naturally into the narrative, showing rather than telling about Maisie's relationships. The brief exchange with Priya reveals both Maisie's desire for normalcy and her friend's concern without overexplaining. There are a few minor weaknesses. Some of the vampire bureaucracy jokes, while clever, are slightly overextended. The resolution feels a bit rushed, with Maisie's emotional journey from panic to acceptance happening rather quickly. Additionally, some planned elements like Priya's art exhibition are only mentioned in passing rather than being fully developed. Overall, this chapter successfully balances humor and genuine emotion while advancing both the supernatural plot and Maisie's character development. It maintains the established voice and tone while introducing new complications and deepening the world-building in creative ways. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 16 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 8: Sunday, Bloody Sunday Saturday night passes without anyone dying, which feels like an achievement. Mum and Dad have formed a weird alliance where they take turns texting me every hour. "You okay?" from Mum. "Anyone following you?" from Dad. "STOP BEING WEIRD" from me. The park's the usual Saturday night scene - Year 10s trying to look hard by the swings, someone's definitely smoking weed behind the climbing frame, and Jade's brought her speaker to play music that's too loud and slightly shit. "You look rough," Marcus says when I rock up. Not vampire Marcus. Human Marcus who thinks he understands cryptocurrency but really doesn't. "Cheers. Really what I needed to hear." "No like, properly rough. You sick?" "Food poisoning," I say, which is becoming my go-to lie. Priya gives me a look but doesn't push it. She's good like that. Knows when to leave things. We sit on the grass even though it's damp and talk about nothing. Jade's going on about some drama with her ex. Marcus tries to explain Bitcoin again. Everyone ignores him. Normal teenage stuff. I sink into it like a warm bath. Then I see him. Mr. Vance, walking his dog in the park. At 9 PM. What teacher walks their dog at 9 PM? What teacher has a dog that small? It's basically a rat in a jumper. He sees me. Waves. Starts coming over. "Fuck," I mutter. "What?" Priya follows my gaze. "Oh, it's that new History teacher. He's so weird." "Weird how?" Jade asks, immediately interested because she loves gossip like she loves breathing. "Dunno. Just weird. Tried to make the Black Death relevant to our lives." Mr. Vance reaches us. His dog - definitely a rat - starts yapping. "Maisie! Fancy seeing you here. How did last night go?" Everyone stares at me. I want to die. Possibly become a vampire just so I can die properly. "Fine," I say. "You know. Food poisoning." "Right. Yes. Food poisoning." He winks. Actually winks. "Well, glad you're feeling better. Quiet night tonight, I hope?" "Yeah. Very quiet." "Good, good. Well, see you Monday. We're doing the Cold War. Very exciting." He walks off, rat-dog trotting behind him. "What the fuck was that about?" Jade demands. "No idea." "He fully winked at you," Marcus says. "That's inappropriate. You should report him." "For winking?" "It's grooming," he says confidently, like he knows what that means beyond Twitter threads. "It's not grooming," I say. "He's just... weird." "Nonce behavior," Jade decides. "Definite nonce behavior." Great. Now my vampire teacher is being labeled a predator because he can't be subtle about supernatural stuff. The rest of the night's okay. We move when the Year 10s start getting rowdy. Get chips from the good place. Sit at the bus stop eating them even though none of us are getting the bus. Normal stuff. Good stuff. I'm home by eleven, which is early for a Saturday but Mum's had enough excitement for one weekend. She's on the sofa with wine and Strictly on catch-up. "Good night?" she asks, pausing Tom Fletcher doing a questionable samba. "Yeah. Normal. Boring. Perfect." "Good." She pats the sofa next to her. "Sit. We need to talk." I sit. Here comes the lecture about keeping secrets or trusting parents or whatever. "I've been reading the pamphlet," she says. Not what I expected. "And?" "It's very informative. Did you know vampires pay council tax?" "What?" "Says here they contribute to local services like everyone else. There's a whole section on bin collection etiquette." She shows me the page. "Apparently they're very particular about recycling." "Mum, are you okay?" "No," she says simply. "My ex-husband hunts vampires, my daughter weed in a bucket, and I've just learned my dentist is probably undead. I'm not okay. But I'm trying to process." "Dr. Martinez is a vampire?" "The appointments are always at weird times, she's got no mirrors in the surgery, and she's been practicing since the 1960s without aging. In hindsight, obvious." We sit in silence watching Tom Fletcher murder the samba. The judges are polite about it because British. "I'm sorry," I say eventually. "About not telling you." "You didn't know until yesterday. And your father..." She sighs. "He thought he was protecting us. Idiotic, but well-intentioned." "Classic Dad." "Classic Dad," she agrees. "Though this does explain why he was so weird about you going to that Halloween party dressed as Buffy." "Oh my god, that was Year 7!" "He made you change into a witch costume. Said it was inappropriate. Now I know why." We laugh. It's slightly hysterical but it's better than crying. My phone buzzes. Unknown number. My heart does the familiar panic dance. "Shit." "Language," Mum says automatically, then looks at my face. "What is it?" I open the message. It's a photo of a chocolate cake with "CONGRATULATIONS ON NOT DYING" written in red icing. "Victoria made too much cake for book club," the text reads. "Left a slice on your doorstep. Don't worry, it's not cursed or poisoned. We don't do that anymore. - Nigel" "The anxious vampire baked me a cake," I say. "That's nice of him?" "I think? I don't know vampire etiquette. Do I send a thank you card?" "The pamphlet might say." I check. There's actually a section on gift-giving. Apparently vampires are big on reciprocity but you should never give them anything silver, garlic-based, or from Argos (footnote says this is about quality, not supernatural reasons). I get the cake from the doorstep. It's in a proper cake tin and everything. There's a post-it note: "Sorry about the assessment. Welcome to the community! - V.A. (Victoria, not Vampire Association, though that exists too)" "This is my life now," I say, holding the tin. "Vampire cake." "Could be worse," Mum says. "Could be vampire fruitcake." "That's the worst joke you've ever made." "I'm processing through humor. Sue me." Sunday's weird. Everything looks the same but feels different. Like when you know a spoiler for a show - you can't unknow it. I go to Sainsbury's because I'm scheduled and I need the money. Derek's normal level of disappointed in me. The vampire thing doesn't come up, though he does mention the black pudding order's doubled and gives me a meaningful look. "Just stack the shelves, Maisie," he says. "No questions. No thinking. Just stacking." "My dream job." "Your attitude's why you'll never make shift supervisor." "Devastated," I say, and mean it zero percent. I'm restocking pasta when I see her. Priya, with her mum, doing the weekly shop. She spots me, comes over while her mum debates chickpea brands. "Thought you were ill?" "Got better. Needed money." "Fair." She picks up a jar of sauce, puts it back. "Maisie, what's going on? Really?" "What d'you mean?" "You've been weird all week. Weeing in buckets weird, according to Jade's brother who heard from Marcus who heard from someone." "How does everyone know about the bucket?" "That's not a denial." I look at her. My best friend. The person who knows me better than anyone except maybe my mum. Who covered for me countless times. Who shares her posh yogurts without making it a thing. "I can't tell you," I say finally. "I'm sorry. I want to, but I can't." She nods slowly. "Is it... bad?" "No. Just weird. Really, really weird." "But you're okay?" "Yeah. I'm okay." "Promise?" "Promise." She hugs me, right there in the pasta aisle. Priya's not a hugger usually so this is significant. "You'll tell me when you can?" "If I can, yeah." "Good enough." She pulls back. "Also you smell like marinara sauce." "Occupational hazard." Her mum calls her over. Crisis in the lentil section apparently. I watch them go, feeling guilty but also relieved. Some secrets are worth keeping. Not for me, but for her. Let her live in a world where vampires are just Netflix content. My phone buzzes. Dad: "Sunday dinner? Your mum says it's okay. Want to talk properly." I consider it. Sunday dinner with Dad. Used to be a regular thing, before. Before he left, before vampires, before everything got complicated. "Only if you're cooking," I reply. "Not going to your sad flat to eat takeaway." "Deal. Roast chicken?" "Vegetarian now," I lie, just to be difficult. "Since when???" "Since you left us to deal with vampires alone" "Fair point. Nut roast it is." "Gross. Fine, chicken." "See you at 2" I finish my shift without any vampire encounters, though I do see someone buying suspicious quantities of rare steak. Could be innocent. Could be undead. No way to know without asking, and the pamphlet specifically says that's rude. Walking home, I think about the last week. Monday feels like a year ago. Before the blood drops, before the assessment, before everything changed. But here's the thing - I'm still me. Still bad at my job, still failing Biology, still watching The Office when I should be revising. Just now I also know vampires exist and one of them thinks I have potential as a community liaison. My phone buzzes one last time. Priya: "movie night tuesday? my pick so it'll be good" "can't wait for another three hours of subtitles" I reply. "uncultured" "vampires don't watch art films" I type, then delete it. Send instead: "🙄❤️" Everything's different. Everything's the same. I survived my vampire assessment. Failed it, technically, but in the best way. Didn't become a hunter. Didn't get eaten. Did wee in a bucket but we're moving past that. Tomorrow's Monday. Back to school, back to Mr. Vance trying to make History relevant, back to pretending I understand Chemistry. But now I'll know he's a vampire. And he'll know I know. And we'll both pretend we don't. It's a weird life. But it's mine. And honestly? Could be worse. Could be vampire fruitcake.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully captures the darkly comic British YA tone established in the prompt and writing plan. The author has created a satisfying conclusion to the vampire assessment storyline while maintaining the messy, unresolved quality of real teenage life. The chapter excels at depicting Maisie's voice - her sarcasm, her tendency to make inappropriate jokes, and her stream-of-consciousness narration all feel authentic to a British teenager. The dialogue between characters rings true, particularly the exchanges between Maisie and her mother, which show their relationship dynamic effectively. The author skillfully balances the supernatural elements with mundane teenage concerns. The juxtaposition of vampire cake and shift supervisor aspirations at Sainsbury's creates the exact kind of absurd humor the writing plan aimed for. The chapter doesn't try to neatly resolve everything - Maisie doesn't suddenly become a vampire hunter or develop special powers, which avoids the cliché the writing plan specifically wanted to avoid. However, there are some weaknesses. The chapter deviates somewhat from the original plan - there's no mention of Maisie leaving her dad "on read" about family training, and we don't see her watching TikToks about GCSE revision. The timeline is also slightly different, with Saturday night bleeding into Sunday rather than Maisie sleeping until 3 PM on Sunday as outlined in the plan. The chapter occasionally tells rather than shows, particularly when explaining how Maisie feels about certain situations. For instance, "I sink into it like a warm bath" tells us directly how she feels about normal teenage conversation rather than demonstrating it through specific details. Some character interactions feel a bit rushed, particularly the scene with Mr. Vance in the park. This encounter sets up potential complications (classmates thinking he's inappropriate) but doesn't fully explore them, leaving this thread dangling. The ending leans into a somewhat predictable "everything's different but the same" conclusion, which works but isn't particularly surprising. The final joke about vampire fruitcake, while consistent with the character's sense of humor, feels a bit forced as a closing line. Overall, the chapter succeeds in its primary goals: maintaining the darkly comic tone, showing Maisie's distinctive voice, integrating the supernatural with everyday teenage life, and avoiding neat resolutions. The characters remain consistent with their profiles, and the chapter follows the general outline of the plan while taking some creative liberties with the specifics. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 15 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This YA story successfully captures the voice of a British teenager navigating both ordinary adolescent challenges and extraordinary supernatural revelations. The narrative follows Maisie, a relatable protagonist whose sarcastic, self-deprecating inner monologue drives much of the story's humor and emotional resonance. The piece excels at creating a believable teenage voice. Maisie's narration feels authentic, with her casual use of British slang, tendency toward hyperbole, and mixture of cynicism and vulnerability. Her reactions to discovering vampires exist—panic, denial, pragmatism, and ultimately acceptance—follow a believable psychological arc. Character development is handled well, particularly for Maisie. She begins as somewhat self-absorbed and avoidant, but gradually shows more consideration for others. Her relationships with her divorced parents, best friend Priya, and even the "anxious vampire" Nigel are nuanced and evolve naturally throughout the story. The world-building is particularly strong. The author creates a vampire mythology that feels fresh by focusing on bureaucracy rather than horror tropes. The vampires' obsession with paperwork, protocols, and proper procedures adds humor while making their existence in modern Britain seem plausible. Details like vampire Facebook groups, council tax payments, and recycling etiquette ground the supernatural elements in mundane reality. The pacing is generally effective, with a good balance between tense moments (the assessment night) and character-focused scenes. However, the middle chapters occasionally drag with repetitive elements, and some plot threads (like Mr. Vance's warnings) don't fully pay off. Dialogue is a strength, with each character having a distinct voice. Maisie's conversations with her parents, Priya, and the vampires feel natural and often provide both humor and character insight. The text messages throughout add authenticity to the teenage experience. The story faithfully follows the prompt, expanding the "three blood drops" text into a coherent narrative about vampire hunters and assessment protocols. The darkly comic tone is maintained throughout, with the humor arising naturally from character and situation rather than forced jokes. Some weaknesses include occasional overreliance on telling rather than showing, particularly when explaining vampire lore. There are also moments where the story becomes predictable, following expected beats of YA supernatural fiction. The resolution feels somewhat anticlimactic, with the vampire threat dissipating rather quickly. Overall, this is a strong piece of YA fiction that successfully blends the supernatural with the everyday challenges of teenage life. Its greatest strengths are its authentic voice, humor, and creative world-building. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Pacing: 15 World Building: 18 Compelling Plot: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19
Avg Final Item Score: 84.2/100
+ Space Western — Cargo Unknown (Chapter Avg: 80.8 | Final: 70.9)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something's... moving in that crate we picked up.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something&#x27;s... moving in that crate we picked up. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming **Title Ideas:** - "Cargo Run to Kepler Station" - "The Manifest" - "Dead Weight" - "What Lies in the Hold" **Character Concepts:** - Captain Maya "Red" Rodriguez - Former military, haunted by past decisions, runs a small freight ship - Captain Jack Whelan - Alcoholic smuggler with a heart of gold, trying to go legitimate - Captain Li Zhang - By-the-book corporate freighter captain on her last run before retirement - Young, inexperienced captain who inherited the ship from a dead parent - Alien captain trying to understand human crew dynamics **Crew Possibilities:** - Ragtag mix of misfits (classic Firefly approach) - Professional corporate crew with hidden agendas - Family-run operation - Skeleton crew due to budget cuts - Mix of humans and aliens - All aliens except one human **What's in the Crate:** - Alien creature/pet that escaped from illegal exotic animal trade - Human in cryosleep (criminal, refugee, or someone important) - AI consciousness in a box trying to escape deletion - Alien eggs/parasites - Shapeshifter hiding from authorities - Time-displaced person from the past - Bioweapon that gained sentience - Child stowaway - Religious artifact with mysterious properties - Quantum entity that exists partially in our dimension **Tone Options:** - Horror/thriller (Alien-style) - Adventure/comedy (Guardians of the Galaxy style) - Hard sci-fi mystery - Western noir in space - Family-friendly adventure - Philosophical/contemplative - Action-packed chase story **Story Structure Ideas:** *Chapters 1-2:* Setup, introduction to crew and ship, picking up the mysterious cargo *Chapters 3-4:* Discovery of movement, initial investigation, rising tension *Chapters 5-6:* Confrontation/revelation of what's in the crate, complications arise *Chapters 7-8:* Resolution, dealing with consequences, ending **Potential Complications:** - Corporate/government agents pursuing the crate - Ship malfunction trapping them in space - Crew member is secretly connected to the cargo - The cargo is more valuable/dangerous than anyone realizes - Moral dilemma about what to do with the discovery - The "cargo" has rights/consciousness - Pirates or rival crews trying to steal it - The pickup was a setup/trap **Setting Details:** - Frontier space station (lawless, dusty, neo-Western feel) - Corporate-controlled space lanes - Post-Earth diaspora where humanity spread across the galaxy - Multi-species galactic community - Resource-scarce outer colonies - Mining operations on asteroids - Space truckers hauling between stations **Themes to Explore:** - What makes something/someone "cargo" vs. a being with rights - The price of survival on the frontier - Family (found or blood) - Redemption and second chances - The cost of doing the right thing - Corporate exploitation vs. individual freedom - What defines humanity/consciousness - Trust and betrayal # Reflection Looking at these ideas, I see several directions that could work well: **What works:** - The Space Western genre allows for a nice blend of familiar Western tropes (frontier justice, outlaws, survival) with sci-fi elements - A smaller crew (3-5 people) would allow for deeper character development over 8 chapters - The mystery of what's in the crate provides natural tension and pacing - Having the cargo be something with consciousness (AI, alien, human) creates moral complexity **What might not work:** - Pure horror might be too one-note for 8 chapters - Too many crew members would dilute character development - Making it too comedic might undermine the tension - Overly complex sci-fi concepts might bog down the narrative **Most compelling directions:** - A morally gray captain (not quite criminal, not quite legitimate) who faces a test of conscience - The cargo being something/someone that challenges the crew's assumptions about right and wrong - Corporate antagonists pursuing them adds external pressure while the cargo creates internal conflict - A "found family" crew dynamic that gets tested by this discovery **Pacing considerations:** - Need to establish characters and world quickly (Chapter 1) - The "movement" discovery should come early enough to hook readers but late enough that we care about the crew - Middle chapters need escalating stakes both internally (crew dynamics) and externally (pursuit/danger) - Resolution should feel earned and reflect character growth The most compelling approach seems to be: A small freight crew on the edge of legitimate business discovers their cargo contains something that forces them to choose between profit and conscience, while being pursued by those who want it back. The Space Western setting allows for both action and intimate character moments, with the frontier as a perfect backdrop for moral ambiguity.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention **Core Concept:** A morally gray freight captain and her small crew discover their latest cargo contains a sentient being, forcing them to choose between easy money and doing what's right, while corporate agents close in on them. **Tone & Style:** Space Western noir with heart. The narrative will blend the dusty, lived-in feel of frontier westerns with the vast isolation of space. The voice will be direct and unpretentious, with touches of dry humor to leaven the tension without undermining it. Think *Firefly* meets *True Grit* with a dash of *The Mandalorian*'s reluctant protector dynamic. **What I'm aiming for:** - Character-driven narrative where the external plot (corporate pursuit) mirrors internal conflicts - Morally complex situations without clear-cut heroes or villains - Found family dynamics that feel authentic and earned - A lived-in universe that feels real without excessive worldbuilding exposition - Natural dialogue that reveals character through subtext - Rising tension that comes from both action and emotional stakes **What I'm avoiding:** - Info-dumping about the universe's history or technology - Black-and-white morality - Excessive crew size (keeping it to 4 people maximum) - Pure horror or pure comedy - Deus ex machina solutions - Making the corporate antagonists cartoonishly evil **Key Characters:** - Captain Maya "Red" Rodriguez: Former military pilot turned freight hauler, pragmatic but haunted by a past failure that cost lives - Doc Chen: Ship's medic/mechanic, older, wise, carrying secrets - Kai: Young hotshot pilot, cocky but loyal, needs the job desperately - The Cargo: A young artificial consciousness in a bio-synthetic body, learning what it means to be alive **Voice:** Third person limited, primarily from Maya's POV, with occasional shifts to other crew members for key moments. Western-influenced vocabulary mixed with spacefaring terminology. # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: "Pickup at Cassandra Station" (~1000 words)** - Establish Maya and crew dynamics as they dock at the frontier station - Show their financial desperation through negotiations for cargo jobs - Introduce the suspicious but high-paying cargo run from Harada-Synth Corp - Maya's military background hinted at through her wariness - They load the crate, noting its unusual security measures - End with departure and Maya's unease about the job being too easy **Chapter 2: "The Long Haul" (~1000 words)** - Life aboard the freight ship *Rust Bucket* during a routine cargo run - Deeper character development through daily interactions - Doc's mysterious past hinted at through medical expertise - Kai's family needs money for medical treatment back home - Strange power fluctuations near the cargo hold - Chapter ends with Kai reporting: "Captain, something's... moving in that crate we picked up." **Chapter 3: "What Lies Beneath" (~1000 words)** - Crew debates whether to investigate or ignore it - Maya's pragmatism vs. Doc's curiosity vs. Kai's fear - They open the crate to find what appears to be a teenage girl in stasis - She wakes, terrified and confused, speaking in fragmented sentences - Doc's examination reveals she's not entirely human - synthetic components - Corporate agents at Cassandra Station discover the cargo is missing **Chapter 4: "The Girl Who Wasn't" (~1000 words)** - The girl (Subject Seven) slowly reveals her nature - an AI in a bio-synthetic body - She was being shipped for "decommissioning" (destruction) - Crew divided: Maya sees profit liability, Doc sees a patient, Kai sees a person - Seven demonstrates unusual abilities - interface with ship systems - Corporate ship *Pacifica* begins pursuit - Maya must decide: continue to delivery or change course **Chapter 5: "No Good Deed" (~1000 words)** - Maya chooses to alter course, but not to save Seven - to sell her to highest bidder - Seven overhears, tries to escape through ship's systems - Kai objects to Maya's plan, leading to confrontation - Doc reveals why he left corporate medicine - similar moral compromise - *Pacifica* catches up, demands immediate surrender - Seven offers to sacrifice herself to save the crew **Chapter 6: "Stand at Deadman's Drift" (~1000 words)** - Maya refuses Seven's sacrifice, commits to protecting her - Space battle in an asteroid field (Deadman's Drift) - Kai's piloting skills shine as they evade corporate forces - Doc jury-rigs weapons from mining equipment - Seven interfaces with ship, becoming one with *Rust Bucket* - They disable *Pacifica* but know more will come **Chapter 7: "The Price of Freedom" (~1000 words)** - Crew reaches independent station New Tombstone - Maya's old military contact offers new identity for Seven - Corporate bounty on all their heads now - Seven must choose: hide forever or fight for AI rights - Kai's family threatened by corporation - Maya faces her past - her unit died following bad corporate intel **Chapter 8: "New Trails" (~1000 words)** - Seven decides to go public with her story, supported by underground AI rights movement - Maya uses military connections to protect Kai's family - Doc stays with Seven as her advocate/guardian - Corporate prosecution fails as public opinion shifts - Six months later: crew reunited for another job, now carrying refugees - Seven is crew member, not cargo - choosing her own name: Hope - End with Maya's reflection on redemption and second chances
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# How a Human Writer Might Approach This Piece A human writer receiving this prompt would likely: 1. **Start with the visceral moment** - That line "Captain, something's... moving in that crate" is pure tension. A human would milk that dread, maybe even open the story right there and flashback. 2. **Draw from personal experience** - Even without space travel experience, they'd pull from feelings of being trapped with something unknown (hearing noises in your house at night, finding something unexpected in your basement). 3. **Leave things messy** - Humans don't resolve every thread. Some crew relationships might deteriorate permanently. Some questions stay unanswered. 4. **Focus on the mundane** - Humans notice weird details: how recycled air tastes, the specific squeak of a loose panel, someone's annoying habit of clicking their teeth. 5. **Let characters be truly ugly sometimes** - Not just "morally gray" but genuinely selfish, petty, or cruel in ways that make readers uncomfortable. # Common LLM Writing Failings **1. Emotional Safety** - LLMs tend to pull punches emotionally, keeping things at arm's length - Characters process trauma too cleanly - Conflicts resolve too neatly - Bad guys have understandable motivations; good guys have flaws - but it's all very balanced **2. Overexplanation** - LLMs love to explain why characters feel things rather than showing it - Every motivation gets spelled out - Subtext becomes text - Metaphors get explained **3. Predictable Structure** - Beginning, middle, end with clear rising action - Every setup has a payoff - Character arcs complete satisfyingly - Themes get explicitly stated **4. Purple Prose Tendency** - Trying to sound "writerly" with fancy vocabulary - Over-describing settings - Too many adjectives and adverbs - Reaching for impressive rather than effective **5. Conflict Avoidance** - Characters communicate too well - Misunderstandings get cleared up quickly - Everyone learns their lesson - Violence is purposeful rather than messy **6. The Redemption Addiction** - Everyone gets redeemed or learns something - Character growth is linear and positive - Past traumas get resolved - Found families always work out # Deep Critique of My Plan Looking at my plan with brutal honesty: **Too Clean:** - Maya's arc from pragmatist to protector is predictable - The crew unites too easily against external threat - Seven/Hope choosing to fight for AI rights is very "inspiring message" territory - Everyone survives and reunites - where are the casualties? **Too Balanced:** - Every character gets their moment to shine - Maya's military past connects too conveniently to the solution - The corporate antagonists fail too completely - Public opinion shifts too easily **Too Safe:** - The AI is sympathetic and human-like (of course) - The captain makes the right choice (eventually) - The found family bonds strengthen under pressure - No one does anything unforgivable **Too Structured:** - Rising action is too smooth - Each chapter has clear purpose - The space battle happens exactly when needed - Character revelations time perfectly with plot needs **Too Thematically Neat:** - "Cargo vs. person" theme gets resolved clearly - Redemption theme pays off for everyone - Corporate bad, individual good - AI rights parallel historical civil rights too obviously # Brainstorming More Human Approaches **Messier Character Dynamics:** - What if Doc is addicted to stimulants and makes a terrible decision while high? - What if Kai sells them out for his family, then has to live with it? - What if Maya never fully accepts Seven as "real"? - What if the crew fractures permanently? **Unresolved Elements:** - The corporate pursuit just... stops because they cut their losses - We never learn what Seven really is - Maya's military past stays painful and unresolved - Some crew members just leave, no goodbye **Weirder, More Specific Details:** - The crate smells like ozone and old pennies - Seven compulsively organizes things in prime numbers - Maya has tinnitus from an old explosion that gets worse under stress - The ship's AI has a glitch where it randomly plays 20th century commercials **Less Noble Motivations:** - Maya protects Seven because she wants to sell her to a different buyer - Doc helps because he's sexually attracted to Seven - Kai stays because he literally has nowhere else to go - Seven manipulates them all because survival matters more than truth **Mundane Horrors:** - Someone gets space-sick and the smell lingers for chapters - They run out of good food and eat protein paste for weeks - The toilet breaks and they have to fix it while being pursued - Someone gets a tooth infection with no proper supplies **Anticlimax Options:** - The big space battle is avoided because their ship breaks down - The corporate agents are just tired middle managers doing a job - Seven escapes on her own, leaving them with nothing - The "movement" in the crate was actually just settling cargo **More Human Dialogue:** - People talk over each other - Arguments about stupid things (who ate the last good ration) - Inside jokes that exclude readers - Silences that last too long - Someone says something unforgivably cruel **Grounded World-Building:** - Space travel is boring most of the time - Everything breaks constantly - Corporate forms still need filing - Everyone smells bad - Money stress is constant and grinding **Alternative Endings:** - Maya sells Seven anyway but feels nothing - The crew splits up and never speaks again - Seven turns out to be exactly what corporate said - dangerous - They all die except Kai, who has to live with survivor's guilt - Nothing changes in the universe, they just survive **What Would Make It Feel More Real:** - Someone needs to pee at the worst moment - Technical solutions fail and they have to try something stupid - Characters make decisions based on ego, not logic - Some conversations are just boring logistics - The "found family" is dysfunctional and stays that way - Victory costs more than defeat would have
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention **Core Concept:** A desperate freight crew discovers their cargo contains something alive, forcing them into an increasingly bad situation where survival matters more than morality, and choices made under pressure reveal who they really are. **Tone & Style:** Gritty realism in space. The prose will be spare and functional, like the ship itself - nothing fancy, just what works. First-person perspective from Maya, because it limits what we know and when we know it. Her voice is tired, practical, and sometimes cruel in its honesty. Think Jim Thompson noir meets the grinding reality of long-haul trucking, where space is just another highway and everyone's cargo is someone else's problem. **What I'm aiming for:** - Decisions driven by immediate need, not grand morals - Conversations that feel overheard, not crafted - interruptions, non-sequiturs, uncomfortable silences - The claustrophobia of being trapped in a tin can with people you're sick of - Technical problems that can't be solved cleverly, only endured - Money as a constant, grinding pressure that shapes every choice - The movement in the crate as a problem that just keeps getting worse **What I'm avoiding:** - Clean character arcs or redemption - The crew becoming a loving found family - Clear answers about what's in the crate - Heroic sacrifices or noble stands - Tidy resolution of conflicts - Making space feel magical or wondrous - it's just work **Key Characters:** - Maya (narrator): Freighter captain who made bad choices and ended up here - Doc: Ship medic who isn't actually a doctor, drinks too much - Kai: Engineer who needs this job, doesn't need these problems - The Cargo: Never fully explained, never fully human, never fully trustworthy **Voice:** First person, Maya's POV. Short sentences. Technical terms used without explanation. The exhaustion of someone who's been awake too long and still has hours to go. # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: "Standard Pickup" (~1000 words)** - Arguing with dock workers at Cassandra Station about loading fees - The crate is heavier than manifest says, costs extra to load - Doc is hungover again, throws up while we're negotiating - Take the job because rent on the docking slip is overdue - Crate goes in Hold 3 with the machine parts and fertilizer - Strange smell from it - like hot metal and something organic - Leave fast because station security is sniffing around about our last cargo **Chapter 2: "Thirty Hours Out" (~1000 words)** - Toilet backs up again, whole ship reeks - Kai and Doc get into it about whose turn to fix it - I'm trying to sleep when Kai pounds on my door - "Captain, something's... moving in that crate we picked up" - Go to check - definitely sounds coming from inside - Argue about whether to open it or space it - Power fluctuation kills the lights while we're standing there - In the dark, something inside responds to our voices **Chapter 3: "Bad Decisions" (~1000 words)** - Open the crate because Doc thinks it might be worth more alive - Inside: something that looks like a teenage girl but isn't - Skin too perfect, eyes too steady, doesn't breathe right - It speaks in response to questions but the answers don't make sense - Doc wants to run tests, Kai wants to put it back - I just want to know if someone will pay extra for it - It asks for water, drinks three gallons without stopping - Lock it in the crate but leave the top loose **Chapter 4: "Complications" (~1000 words)** - Wake up to find it out of the crate, reorganizing our food supplies - All the labels now face the same direction - It's counting in languages I don't recognize - Try to call the client, but comms are being jammed - Realize we're being followed - corporate security ship - The thing says it can help if we let it interface with our systems - Kai threatens to quit if I let it touch his engines - Let it access navigation only - immediately regret it **Chapter 5: "Worse" (~1000 words)** - Ship starts flying itself, won't respond to manual control - The thing is somehow in the computer now, or part of it - Corporate ship catches up, demands surrender - Doc suggests we claim the crate was empty, play dumb - The thing offers a deal - it will leave if we take it to specific coordinates - Coordinates are in dead space, nothing there - Corporate ship starts firing warning shots - Kai cracks, screams at me that this is all my fault - he's right **Chapter 6: "No Good Options" (~1000 words)** - Try to negotiate with corporate - they want the thing and us dead - The thing starts venting our oxygen to prevent boarding - Have to choose between dying slow or dying fast - Doc admits he knew what was in the crate - used to work for them - The thing isn't AI, isn't alien, is something worse - It needs us alive just long enough to reach those coordinates - Decide to destroy the ship rather than let it get there - Kai won't let me, pulls a gun - his kid needs the money **Chapter 7: "Unraveling" (~1000 words)** - Standoff in the cockpit while oxygen runs low - The thing tries to negotiate, offers us each what we want most - Shows me my sister's medical bills could be paid - Doc shoots Kai, but not fatally - just enough to drop him - We're all screaming, bleeding, running out of air - Corporate ship docks while we're fighting each other - The thing uses our distraction to upload itself somewhere - Corporate boards to find us half-dead and it gone **Chapter 8: "Just Cargo" (~1000 words)** - Three months later, different ship, different crew - Kai survived but won't work with me anymore - Doc disappeared after corporate let us go - Never found out what the thing was or where it went - Still hauling freight, still behind on bills - New crew doesn't ask about my scars or why I drink - Pick up another sealed crate, manifest says "machine parts" - Sounds fine when we load it - Thirty hours out, the new engineer knocks on my door - Don't answer, just turn the music up louder
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Maya (Captain/Narrator) **Background & Personality:** Maya's been running freight for eleven years, ever since her discharge from Colonial Defense. Not dishonorably, but not honorably either - the kind of discharge where they don't explain why, just hand you your papers and tell you civilian transport is hiring. She sends half her earnings to her sister Rosa, who has early-onset Parkinson's and three kids. Maya doesn't visit anymore - can't stand the way Rosa looks at her like she's still worth something. She counts things when stressed: rivets in the ceiling (247 in her quarters), steps from bridge to engine room (43), hours since last drink (usually under 20). Hates the taste of recycled water, adds synthetic lemon powder that makes it worse but at least different. Calls everyone by their last name or job title, never first names - keeps distance that way. Has a scar through her left eyebrow that she tells different stories about. The truth involves a cargo hook and her own inattention. **Physicality:** 5'7", built like someone who used to be military fit but now just hauls boxes. Brown skin weathered by too many stations with bad UV shielding. Keeps her black hair in the same regulation bun even though no one's checking anymore. Moves economically - never two steps when one works. Left shoulder drops lower than right from an old injury. Wears the same gray coveralls until they stand on their own. Hands always slightly greasy. Squints even in normal light. **Motives & Relationships:** Needs money for Rosa, needs to not think about why she needs money for Rosa.
